Definition: A penalty is a punishment, given when someone breaks a rule or law.
Example: I had to pay a $ 100 penalty for parking in the wrong spot.
Cambridge Examples:
• The law carries a penalty of up to three years in prison.
• They asked for the maximum penalty for hoax calls to be increased to one year.
• The protesters were told to clear the area around the building, on penalty of arrest (= or be arrested) if they did not.

Definition: When someone is rude, they are mean and not polite.
Example: The children at the bus stop were very rude.
Cambridge Examples:
• He's a very rude man.
• It's rude not to say "Thank you" when you are given something.
• He's got no manners - he's rude to everyone.
• He shouted a collection of rude words at me and stormed off.

Definition: To settle a problem means to end it by finding a solution.
Example: It took three of our best executives all day to settle the problem.
Cambridge Examples:
• Good, that's all settled - you send out the invitations for the party, and I'll organize the food.
• [ + question word ] They haven't yet settled when the wedding is going to be.
• "The tickets are €40 each." "Well, that settles that - I can't afford that much."
• I'd like to get this matter settled once and for all (= reach a final decision on it).

Definition: A vehicle is a thing that moves people or things to another place.
Example: A ferry is a vehicle that takes people from one island to another.
Cambridge Examples:
• A truck driver died last night when his vehicle overturned.
• Road vehicles include cars, buses, and trucks.
• Tractors are farm vehicles.
• The number of thefts of motor vehicles rose by a third last year.
• In a racing video game the player takes part in a racing competition with land, air, or sea vehicles.

Definition: To yell is to say something very loudly.
Example: The coach yelled at his team for their poor performance.
Cambridge Examples:
• Our neighbours were yelling (obscenities) at each other this morning.
• The child yelled out in pain.
• [ + speech ] "Just get out of here!" she yelled.

Definition: To accuse someone of something is to blame them for doing it.
Example: She accused her brother of breaking her computer.
Cambridge Examples:
• "It wasn't my fault." "Don't worry, I'm not accusing you."
• He's been accused of robbery/murder.
• Are you accusing me of lying?
• The surgeon was accused of negligence.

Definition: To adjust something means to change it so it is better.
Example: He adjusted the old guitar to make it sound better.
Cambridge Examples:
• If the chair is too high you can adjust it to suit you.
• As a teacher you have to adjust your methods to suit the needs of slower children.

Definition: To amuse someone means to do something that is funny or entertaining.
Example: The singer was very good. She amused the crowd.
Cambridge Examples:
• I've brought an article from yesterday's paper that I thought might amuse you.
• [ + obj + to infinitive ] I think it amuses him to see people make fools of themselves.
• Apparently these stories are meant to amuse.

Definition: cotton is thread or cloth made from the fiber surrounding the seeds of a tall plant, or these fibers themselves.
Example: I like to wear clothes made from cotton in the summer.
Cambridge Examples:
• a shirt made of pure cotton
• She looked pretty in a simple cotton dress.
• UK a reel of cotton (= thread)

Definition: To crash means to hit and break something.
Example: There was a loud noise when the car crashed into the tree.
Cambridge Examples:
• We skidded on the ice and crashed.
• The plane crashed into a mountainside.
• Her brother borrowed her motorbike and crashed it.

Definition: A deck is a wooden floor built outside of a house or the floor of a ship.
Example: A ship will store many supplies below its deck.
Cambridge Examples: • We sat on deck until it was dark.

Definition: When something is firm, it is not soft but not completely hard
Example: He sleeps better on a firm bed.
Cambridge Examples:
• I'd rather sleep on a firm mattress than a soft one.
• These pears are still too firm to eat.

Definition: fuel is something that creates heat or energy.
Example: Heat is the fuel that comes from fire.
Cambridge Examples:
• Wood, coal, oil, petrol, and gas are all different kinds of fuel.
• Plutonium is a fuel used to produce nuclear energy.
• nuclear fuel
• unleaded fuel
• The new exhaust system, it is claimed, will lower fuel consumption.

Definition: A loss means the act or an instance of losing something.
Example: I suffered a big loss while I was gambling.
Cambridge Examples:
• Many parents feel a sense of loss when their children leave home.
• He suffered a gradual loss of memory.
• There will be substantial job losses if the factory closes down.
• He suffered hearing loss from testing aircraft engines.
• blood/hair/weight loss

Definition: If something is simple, it is plain and not decorated.
Example: He bought a pair of plain white shoes over the weekend.
Cambridge Examples:
• She wore a plain black dress.
• We've chosen a plain carpet (= one without a pattern) and patterned curtains.
• He prefers plain food - nothing too fancy.
• We're having plain blue walls in the dining room.
• a catalogue sent in a plain brown envelope
• a plain style of architecture
• plain yogurt (= with no added fruit or sugar)

Definition: When someone is strict, they make sure others follow rules.
Example: The teacher is strict. She does not let students talk in class.
Cambridge Examples:
• My parents were very strict with me when I was young.
• Stricter controls on air pollution would help to reduce acid rain.
• A strict curfew has been imposed from dusk till dawn.
• We follow very strict guidelines on the use and storage of personal details on computers.
• Do you think stricter gun laws would reduce the murder rate in the United States?
• The drug should only be administered under strict medical supervision.
• The negotiations took place in strict (= total) secrecy.

Definition: To surf means to use a special board to ride on waves in the ocean.
Example: The students went to the beach to surf during their vacation.
Cambridge Examples: • They go surfing every weekend.

Definition: A task is a piece of work to be done that is usually difficult.
Example: My task for the weekend was to clean the entire back yard.
Cambridge Examples:
• We usually ask interviewees to perform a few simple tasks on the computer just to test their aptitude.
• The government now faces the daunting task of restructuring the entire health service.

Definition: A zone is an area that has different qualities from the ones around it.
Example: Firefighters often work in danger zones.
Cambridge Examples:
• an earthquake zone
• a nuclear-free zone
• He was charged with driving at 75 mph in a 55 mph zone.
• This stretch of coast has been designated a danger zone.
• The UN Security Council has established a no-fly zone (= one where aircraft are not permitted to fly).

Definition: An apology is something someone says to show that they are sorry.
Example: After arguing with her teacher, the girl wrote the teacher an apology.
Cambridge Examples:
• I have an apology to make to you - I'm afraid I opened your letter by mistake.
• He's demanding a full apology from the newspaper for making untrue allegations about his personal life.
• "Was he at all sorry for what he'd done?" "Oh he was full of apologies (= extremely sorry)."
• She complained to the company and they sent her a written apology.
• I owe you an apology - I'm afraid I forgot to send that report.
• a letter of apology

Definition: If someone is bold, they are not afraid of doing something.
Example: The bold man climbed the high mountain.
Cambridge Examples:
• She was a bold and fearless climber.
• The newspaper made the bold move/took the bold step of publishing the names of the men involved.

Definition: To capture someone or something is to catch them.
Example: James tried to capture the bubbles in his hands.
Cambridge Examples:
• Two of the soldiers were killed and the rest were captured.
• Rebel forces captured the city after a week-long battle.

Definition: If people feel guilty, they feel bad for what they did.
Example: I felt guilty for taking my sister's cookies.
Cambridge Examples:
• I feel so guilty about forgetting her birthday.
• She must have done something wrong, because she's looking so guilty.
• You've got a guilty conscience - that's why you can't sleep.

Definition: To hire someone is to pay them money to work for you.
Example: We hired a man to paint our house.
Cambridge Examples:
• I was hired by the first company I applied to.
• [ + to infinitive ] We ought to hire a public relations consultant to help improve our image.

Definition: If someone is innocent, they are not guilty of a crime.
Example: The judge said that the woman was innocent of the crime.
Cambridge Examples: • He firmly believes that she is innocent of the crime.

Definition: jail is a place where criminals go to be punished.
Example: The thief was caught and sent to jail for ten years.
Cambridge Examples:
• the country's overcrowded jails
• a 13-year jail sentence/term
• The financier was released from jail last week.
• They spent ten years in jail for fraud.
• They don't throw anyone in jail for parking illegally, but they will tow your car and charge you a fine.

Definition: A minister is an important person in government with many duties.
Example: The minister of education controls the country's schools.
Cambridge Examples:
• the foreign/health minister
• the Minister of/for Education

Definition: If someone or something is ordinary, they are not special in any way.
Example: Today was just an ordinary day. Nothing unusual happened.
Cambridge Examples:
• an ordinary neighbourhood
• Readers of the magazine said they wanted more stories about ordinary people and fewer stories about the rich and famous.
• Her last concert appearance in Britain was no ordinary (= a very special) performance.

Definition: If something is permanent, it lasts for a long time or forever.
Example: We don't know if Aunt Mildred's visit will be a permanent one.
Cambridge Examples:
• She is looking for a permanent place to stay.
• Are you looking for a temporary or a permanent job?
• The disease can cause permanent damage to the brain.
• A semi-permanent hair dye will wash out after about three months.
• He entered the United States in 1988 as a permanent resident because of his marriage to a U.S. citizen.

Definition: To preserve is to protect something from harm.
Example: Dad sprayed a chemical on the house to help preserve its looks.
Cambridge Examples:
• to preserve the environment
• We want to preserve the character of the town while improving the facilities.
• The agreement preserved our right to limit trade in endangered species.
• Putting varnish on wood is a way of preserving it.
• I need to get out of the house from time to time just to preserve (= prevent me from losing) my sanity.

Definition: To pronounce is to say the sounds of letters or words.
Example: Young children often have trouble pronouncing words right.
Cambridge Examples:
• How do you pronounce your surname?
• She pronounced his name so badly he didn't even recognize it.
• Sade, pronounced shah-day, is a singer.

Definition: twins are two children born at the same time.
Example: My sister and I are twins. We look exactly the same.
Cambridge Examples:
• My sister has twin sons.
• a twin sister

Definition: To accompany other people means to join them or go with them.
Example: My brothers accompanied me to the movie.
Cambridge Examples:
• The course books are accompanied by four CDs.
• Depression is almost always accompanied by insomnia.
• The salmon was accompanied by (= served with) a fresh green salad.

Definition: When something is bare, it is plain. It has no covering.
Example: He likes to walk around in his bare feet.
Cambridge Examples:
• Don't walk around outside in your bare feet.
• There's no carpet in the room, just bare floorboards.

Definition: A branch is the part of a tree with leaves.
Example: The monkey was hanging from a branch on the tree.
Cambridge Examples:
• bare/leafy/flowering branches
• The fruit on the lower branches was protected from the sun.
• Watch out for overhanging branches.

Definition: A breath is the air that goes into and out of one's lungs.
Example: You can't take a breath under water.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her breath smelled of garlic.
• She was dizzy and short of breath (= unable to breathe in enough air).
• He burst into the room, red-faced and out of breath (= unable to breathe comfortably because of tiredness or excitement).

Definition: To dare means to be brave enough to try something.
Example: He dared to jump out of the airplane and skydive.
Cambridge Examples:
• I was going to ask if his dog was better, but I didn't dare in case she had died.
• [ + (to) infinitive ] Everyone in the office complains that he smells awful, but nobody dares (to) mention it to him.
• [ + infinitive without to ] I wouldn't dare have a party in my flat in case the neighbours complained.
• Dare you tell him the news?
• I don't dare think how much it's going to cost.
• UK I daren't think how much it's going to cost.
• UK Do you dare (to) tell him the news?
• I'd never dare (to) talk to my mother the way Brandon talks to his.
• [ + to infinitive ] He was under attack for daring to criticize the mayor.

Definition: When something is electronic, it uses electricity to do something.
Example: I like having electronic devices such as an MP3 player.
Cambridge Examples:
• an electronic keyboard/game
• electronic components/devices

Definition: A net is a bag made of strong thread. It is used to catch animals.
Example: The boy caught butterflies in his net.
Cambridge Examples:
• a fishing net
• a butterfly net
• Dolphins often get tangled in the nets that are used to catch tuna fish.
• UK The living-room windows have net curtains that let in sunlight but stop passers-by looking in from the street.

Definition: A philosophy is a way to think about truth and life.
Example: My philosophy is "live and let live".
Cambridge Examples: • René Descartes is regarded as the founder of modern philosophy.

Definition: A pot is a deep, round metal container used for cooking.
Example: Don't touch the pot on the stove. It's hot.
Cambridge Examples:
• Fill a large pot with salted water and bring it to the boil.
• There's plenty of cupboard space in the kitchen for all your pots and pans.

Definition: A seed is the hard part of a plant or fruit that trees grow from.
Example: I planted the seed in the dirt hoping that it would grow into a tree.
Cambridge Examples:
• Sow the seeds (= put them in the ground) about three centimetres deep.
• The chemical will stop all seeds from sprouting (= starting to grow).
• The farmers grow these crops for seed (= for planting to grow more crops, rather than for eating).

Definition: When something is sharp, it has a thin edge that cuts things easily.
Example: That knife is very sharp. Be careful not to hurt yourself.
Cambridge Examples:
• a knife with a sharp edge/blade.
• sharp teeth/claws/fingernails
• The point of this pencil isn't sharp enough.

Definition: When something is tight, it is fixed or fastened firmly in place.
Example: The knots were too tight to untie.
Cambridge Examples:
• I can't untie the knot - it's too tight.
• This lid is on very tight.
• The people stood talking in tight groups.
• Hold on tight when we go around the corner.
• Check that windows and doors are shut tight (= completely closed) before you leave.
• The plastic cover was stretched tight (= stretched as much as it could be) across the tank.
• It is a tight squeeze on some trains, the General Manager acknowledged (= passengers are packed closely together).

Definition: To weigh something means to see how heavy it is.
Example: The little dog weighed exactly 3 kgs.
Cambridge Examples:
• Yesterday a satellite weighing 15 tons was successfully placed in orbit.
• She weighs herself every week on the scales in the bathroom.
• Your luggage must be weighed before it is put on the aircraft.

Definition: To whisper means to say very quietly.
Example: We have to whisper in the library so people can focus on reading.
Cambridge Examples:
• She leaned over and whispered something in his ear.
• What are you two girls whispering about?
• [ + speech ] "Where are the toilets?" she whispered.
• It's rude to whisper!

Definition: If ideas are abstract, they are based on general ways of thinking.
Example: The idea of beauty is abstract and changes over time.
Cambridge Examples: • Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.

Definition: If something is annual, it happens once a year.
Example: The only time I see my aunts and uncles is at our annual family picnic.
Cambridge Examples:
• an annual event/visit/holiday
• Companies publish annual reports to inform the public about the previous year's activities.

Definition: cloth is material used to make clothes.
Example: His shirt is made of a very soft type of cloth.
Cambridge Examples: • a piece/length of cloth

Definition: To deserve is to be worthy of something as a result of one's actions.
Example: The dog deserved a bone for behaving very well.
Cambridge Examples:
• After all that hard work, you deserve a holiday.
• Chris deserves our special thanks for all his efforts.
• I hope they get the punishment they deserve.
• [ + to infinitive ] They certainly deserved to win that game.

Definition: feathers are the things covering birds' bodies.
Example: That bird has orange feathers on its chest.
Cambridge Examples:
• peacock/ostrich feathers
• feather pillows (= those containing feathers)
• The bird ruffled its feathers.

Definition: A flood is an event in which water covers an area which is usually dry.
Example: After three days of rain, threre was a flood in the city.
Cambridge Examples:
• After the flood it took weeks for the water level to go down.
• The river is in flood (= water has flowed over its banks) again.

Definition: A grave is the place where a dead person is buried.
Example: We visit our grandfather's grave each year.
Cambridge Examples:
• a mass grave
• an unmarked grave
• a grave digger
• He visits his mother's grave every Sunday.

Definition: If something is ideal, it is the best that it can possibly be.
Example: This house is an ideal place for my family. It has everything we need.
Cambridge Examples:
• the ideal employer
• She's the ideal person (= exactly the right type of person) for the job.
• The television also comes in a compact 36 cm screen size, ideal for bedroom or kitchen use.
• It's the ideal opportunity to meet people.
• In an ideal world no one would go hungry.

Definition: intelligence is the ability to learn and understand things.
Example: Because of his high intelligence, he finished school early.
Cambridge Examples:
• an intelligence test
• a child of high/average/low intelligence
• It's the intelligence of her writing that impresses me.

Definition: If something happens nowadays, it happens at the present time.
Example: In the past people walked everywhere. nowadays, they use cars.
Cambridge Examples:
• Who remembers those movies nowadays?
• Nowadays, I bake my own bread rather than buy it.

Definition: To obtain is to get something you want or need.
Example: After I passed the test, I obtained my driver's license.

Definition: When something is religious, it has to do with religion.
Example: The holy man spoke about religious topics.
Cambridge Examples: • religious education

Definition: When something is romantic, it has to do with love.
Example: The young couple went to see a romantic movie.
Cambridge Examples:
• a romantic novel/comedy
• You used to be so romantic, but now you never tell me that you love me.
• I suppose he is quite romantic - he sends me flowers on my birthday and tells me I'm looking beautiful and so on.

Definition: A shell is a hard covering that protects the body of some sea creatures.
Example: There were many pretty shells on the beach.
Cambridge Examples:
• Brazil nuts have very hard shells.
• A piece of shell fell into the cake mixture.
• the shell of a snail/crab/tortoise
• a shell necklace (= a piece of jewellery made out of the shells of small sea creatures)

Definition: A shore is the edge of a large body of water.
Example: All of the boats were floating near the shore.
Cambridge Examples:
• You can walk for miles along the shore.
• The boat was about a mile from/off (the) shore when the engine suddenly died.

Definition: To appeal to someone is to be interesting or attractive to them.
Example: Sleeping all day appeals to me, but I have to go to school.
Cambridge Examples:
• It's a programme designed to appeal mainly to 16 to 25-year-olds.
• I think what appeals to me about his painting is his use of colour.
• UK I haven't been skiing - it's never really appealed.

Definition: To assume something is to think that it is true, even with no proof.
Example: I assume you are both familiar with this plan.
Cambridge Examples:
• [ + (that) ] I assumed (that) you knew each other because you went to the same school.
• Let's assume (that) they're coming and make plans on that basis.
• [ + to infinitive ] We can't assume the suspects to be guilty simply because they've decided to remain silent.
• We mustn't assume the suspects' guilt.

Definition: A client is a person or business that pays another to do a service.
Example: She has many clients who enjoy coming to her salon.
Cambridge Examples:
• Mr Black has been a client of this firm for many years.
• We always aim to give our clients personal attention.

Definition: If something is dull, it is not exciting.
Example: The movie was very dull. I fell asleep watching it.
Cambridge Examples:
• She wrote dull, respectable articles for the local newspaper.
• He's pleasant enough, but deadly dull.

Definition: A fare is an amount of money paid to use a bus, train, or taxi.
Example: Since he is a senior, my grandfather pays a low fare for the bus.
Cambridge Examples: • Train fares are going up again.

Definition: To found a company or organization means to start it.
Example: The pilgrims founded one of the first colonies in the United States.
Cambridge Examples:
• Boston was founded in 1630 by Puritan colonists from England.
• She left a large sum of money in her will to found a wildlife sanctuary.
• We are planning a dinner to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the founding of the company.

Definition: To invest means to use money in a way that will bring a profit later.
Example: I invested money in a new building that should bring me a profit.
Cambridge Examples:
• The institute will invest five million in the project.
• He's not certain whether to invest in the property market.
• You have all invested significant amounts of time and energy in making this project the success that it is.

Definition: A quarter is 25 cents.
Example: He paid a quarter for the candy.

Definition: A salary is how much money a person makes at his or her job.
Example: He got a new job with a better salary.
Cambridge Examples:
• an annual salary of £40,000
• His net monthly salary is €2,500.
• She's on quite a good/decent salary in her present job.
• He took a drop in (= accepted a lower) salary when he changed jobs.
• a ten percent salary increase

Definition: If something is temporary, it exists for a short time.
Example: This car is only temporary; I'll get a new one soon.
Cambridge Examples:
• The ceasefire will only provide a temporary solution to the crisis.
• temporary staff

Definition: A treasure is a collection of valuable things, especially jewels or gold.
Example: They became very rich when they found the buried treasure.
Cambridge Examples:
• Stories about pirates often include a search for buried treasure.
• When they opened up the tomb they found treasure beyond their wildest dreams.

Definition: A chimney is a tall pipe used to carry smoke out of a building.
Example: The cat was on the roof sitting next to the chimney.
Cambridge Examples: • Factory chimneys belched dense white smoke into the sky.

Definition: iron is a strong metal that is used to make many objects.
Example: The horse had shoes made of iron.
Cambridge Examples:
• Iron rusts easily.
• Liver is a particularly rich source of dietary iron.
• iron ore
• an iron deficiency

Definition: A ladder is an object that is used to climb up and down things.
Example: He used  a ladder to climb to the top of his tree house.
Cambridge Examples: • She was up a ladder, cleaning the window.

Definition: To occupy a place is to live, work, or be there.
Example: Kevin and Alice occupied the chairs and had a long discussion.
Cambridge Examples:
• The rest of the time was occupied with writing a report.
• The house hasn't been occupied (= lived in) by anyone for a few months.
• formal A large picture of the battle of Waterloo occupied the space above the fireplace.

Definition: A penny is a coin worth one cent.
Example: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln is on the penny.
Cambridge Examples:
• Could you lend me 50 pence/50p please?
• I found a ten/twenty/fifty pence piece (= a coin of this value) on the floor.
• I keep pennies and other small coins in a jar.

Definition: satisfaction is a feeling you get when you do or receive something good.
Example: Brad was filled with satisfaction when he saw what was for dinner.
Cambridge Examples:
• She looked at the finished painting with satisfaction.
• She derived/obtained great satisfaction from/out of helping other people.
• For me, job satisfaction is more important than the money.
• She had the satisfaction of knowing that she'd done everything she could.

Definition: To acquire something is to gain possession of it.
Example: Tina acquired a strange package yesterday.
Cambridge Examples:
• He acquired the firm in 2008.
• I was wearing a newly/recently acquired jacket.
• I seem to have acquired (= have got although I don't know how) two copies of this book.
• He has acquired a reputation for being difficult to work with.

Definition: If something is awkward, it is embarrassing and uncomfortable.
Example: After dropping his coffee cup, Robbie felt awkward.
Cambridge Examples:
• It's an awkward corner, so take it slowly.
• Some of the questions were rather awkward.
• It was an awkward ascent, but we reached the top eventually.
• [ + to infinitive ] My car's quite awkward to drive.
• He's an awkward customer (= a difficult person to deal with).

Definition: To deceive someone is to make them believe something that is not true.
Example: He tried to deceive his friends as they were playing a game.
Cambridge Examples:
• The company deceived customers by selling old computers as new ones.
• The sound of the door closing deceived me into thinking they had gone out.

Definition: To discourage someone is to make them feel less excited about something.
Example: Mr. Perry discouraged the students from quitting school.
Cambridge Examples: • The thought of how much work she had to do discouraged her.

Definition: A hut is a house made of wood, grass, or mud that has only one or two rooms.
Example: We all went into the hut to sleep.
Cambridge Examples:
• a mountain hut
• a row of beach huts

Definition: An offense is behavior that is wrong or breaks a law.
Example: Stealing a car is a very serious offense.
Cambridge Examples:
• a serious/minor offence
• a criminal/drink-driving offence
• Driving without a licence is an offence.
• He committed several serious offences.
• It's the third time that he's been convicted of a drug offence.

Definition: To repay is to pay back or to reward someone or something.
Example: She repayid her friend for all of his hard work with a small gift.
Cambridge Examples:
• He had to sell his car to repay the bank loan.
• She repaid the loan to her mother.
• [ + two objects ] She repaid her mother the loan.
• How can I ever repay you for all your kindness?

Definition: If something is ridiculous, it is silly or strange.
Example: Steve looked ridiculous with those huge blue sunglasses.
Cambridge Examples:
• Do I look ridiculous in this hat?
• Don't be so ridiculous! I can't possibly afford to stay in a hotel like that.
• It's ridiculous to expect a two-year-old to be able to read!

Definition: If something is satisfactory, it is good enough.
Example: Mina often received satisfactory grades since she studied so hard.
Cambridge Examples:
• The teachers seem to think his work is satisfactory.
• We hope very much to find a satisfactory solution to the problem.
• The outcome of the discussion was highly satisfactory (= very pleasing).

Definition: wheat is a plant which makes grain. Its grain is used to make bread.
Example: The field of golden wheat was ready to be harvested.
Cambridge Examples:
• wheat fields
• Wheat is a staple crop for millions of people across the world.

Definition: A bunch is a group of the same things.
Example: She was hungry, so she ate the entire bunch of grapes.
Cambridge Examples:
• a bunch of flowers/grapes/bananas/keys
• mainly US informal The reorganization will give us a whole bunch (= a lot) of problems.

Definition: When something is decent, it is OK or good enough.
Example: Eric did a decent job painting the fence.
Cambridge Examples:
• Everyone should be entitled to a decent wage/standard of living.
• I thought he was a decent person.
• It was very decent (= kind) of you to help.
• It made quite a decent-sized (= large) hole.
• After the recent scandal, the priest is expected to do the decent thing and resign from his position.

Definition: disgrace is the loss of other people’s respect because you have done something they strongly disapprove of.
Example: His actions brought disgrace on the family.
Cambridge Examples:
• They were sent home in disgrace.
• He brought disgrace on the whole team by falsifying the results.

Definition: The elbow is the middle part of a person's arm that lets you bend it.
Example: She pointed to her elbow to show me where she hurt herself.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her arm was bandaged from the elbow to the fingers.
• The sleeve of his shirt was torn at the elbow.

Definition: When you are grateful for something, you are happy that it happened.
Example: The girls were grateful to have a chance to spend time with their grandfather.
Cambridge Examples:
• I'm so grateful (to you) for all that you've done.
• If you could get that report finished by Thursday, I'd be very grateful.
• After the earthquake we felt grateful to be alive.
• I'm just grateful that I'm not still working for him.
• formal I would be most grateful if you would send me the book immediately.

Definition: When something is loose, it is not held in place well.
Example: The bolt was loose, so I tightened it with the wrench.
Cambridge Examples:
• There were some loose wires hanging out of the wall.
• The nails in the wall had worked themselves loose.
• The prisoners were so thin that their skin hung loose.

Definition: To offend someone means to make them angry or upset.
Example: They were both offended by what they had said to each other.
Cambridge Examples:
• [ + that ] I think she was offended that she hadn't been invited to the party.
• He looked offended when you called him middle-aged.
• If the sight of a few dirty dishes offends you, then I think you're in trouble!

Definition: When something happens overnight, it happens during the night.
Example: The campers stayed in the tent overnight.
Cambridge Examples:
• an overnight stop in Paris
• You can stay overnight if you want to.
• Don't forget to pack an overnight bag (= a bag for things that you need when you stay away from home for a night).

Definition: A pine is a type of tree that is tall and thin. An evergreen tree that grows in cooler areas of the world.
Example: There were many beautiful pine trees in the forest.
Cambridge Examples:
• a plantation of pines
• a pine forest

Definition: A scar is a mark on the skin after a wound heals.
Example: The monster had horrible scars on his cheek and forehead.
Cambridge Examples:
• a prominent/a noticeable/an ugly scar
• That burn will leave a bad scar.
• scar tissue

Definition: A sensation is a feeling a person gets from their senses.
Example: Mom got a painful sensation in her head from the loud noise.
Cambridge Examples:
• a burning sensation
• I had no sensation of pain whatsoever.
• The disease causes a loss of sensation in the fingers.

Definition: To tease someone means to laugh at or make fun of them.
Example: Jake teased Charlie because he was the new student.
Cambridge Examples:
• I used to hate being teased about my red hair when I was at school.
• I was just teasing, I didn't mean to upset you.

Definition: To decay is to be destroyed naturally.
Example: The old wooden house was slowly decaying.
Cambridge Examples:
• Sugar makes your teeth decay.
• The role of the extended family has been decaying for some time.
• Pollution has decayed the surface of the stonework on the front of the cathedral.
• the smell of decaying meat

Definition: To dip something is to put part of it into a liquid for a short time.
Example: Laurel dipped her strawberry into the chocolate.
Cambridge Examples:
• Dip the fish in the batter, then drop it into the hot oil.
• She dipped her toe into the pool to see how cold it was.

Definition: If something is distant, it is far away.
Example: Michael could barely see the distant island.
Cambridge Examples:
• a distant country
• She could hear the distant sound of fireworks exploding.

Definition: leisure is time when you do not have to do work.
Example: Eve likes to listen to music in her leisure time.
Cambridge Examples:
• leisure activities
• Most people only have a limited amount of leisure time.
• The town lacks leisure facilities such as a swimming pool or squash courts.

Definition: mankind is all of the world's people.
Example: All of mankind has to work to make this a better world.
Cambridge Examples: • Mankind has always been obsessed by power.

Definition: To sneeze is to suddenly blow air out of your nose and mouth.
Example: He sneezed after smelling the flower.
Cambridge Examples: • Cats make him sneeze - I think he's allergic to them.

Definition: A spice is a flavor for food and drinks.
Example: Two common spices found in many homes are salt and pepper.
Cambridge Examples:
• Cinnamon, ginger, and cloves are all spices.
• Spices are widely used in South Asian cooking.

Definition: To whistle is to make a sound by putting your lips together and blowing.
Example: As he was listening to music, Daryl whistled.
Cambridge Examples:
• He whistled as he worked.
• On the days when she wore a skirt the men on the building site would whistle at her.
• Someone was whistling Beatles tunes outside my window.
• The referee whistled and the game was over.

Definition: A cemetery is where people are buried when they die.
Example: Some people are scared of cemeter<u>i</u>es.
Cambridge Examples:
• His father is buried in the cemetery on the hill.
• We came across a run-down cemetery, full of tumbled gravestones.
• At the far side of the cemetery a group of mourners stood in a circle around the grave.
• He goes down to the cemetery every week to lay flowers on her grave.
• He is in charge of a large municipal cemetery on the outskirts of the city.

Definition: A disguise is something you wear so people cannot tell who you are.
Example: Everyone knew that it was Dad in the Santa disguise.
Cambridge Examples: • He put on a large hat and glasses as a disguise and hoped no one would recognize him.

Definition: A flashlight is a small electric light that you carry in your hand.
Example: We took a flashlight when we went camping.
Cambridge Examples: • She shone the flashlight into the dark room.

Definition: A hood is part of a coat that goes over your head.
Example: She put on her hood to keep her head warm.
Cambridge Examples: • The coat has a detachable hood.

Definition: An inhabitant is a person who lives in a certain place.
Example: The number of inhabitants in the countryside is increasing.
Cambridge Examples: • a city of five million inhabitants

Definition: A pirate is a sailor who steals things from other boats.
Example: pirates are very scary characters.
Cambridge Examples: • The pirates attempted to board the oil tanker.

Definition: A publication is something printed, like a newspaper or book.
Example: She's been a subscriber to that publication for over ten years.
Cambridge Examples: • Our latest publication is a magazine for health enthusiasts.

Definition: If something will happen shortly, it will happen very soon.
Example: My workday will end shortly.
Cambridge Examples: • We will shortly be arriving in King's Cross Station.

Definition: A skeleton is the bones of a body.
Example: There is a skeleton in the science classroom.
Cambridge Examples:
• We found an old sheep skeleton up on the cliffs.
• figurative Her long illness reduced her to a skeleton (= made her very thin).

Definition: To chop something means to cut it into pieces with a tool.
Example: Mom chopped some vegetables to put into the stew.
Cambridge Examples:
• He was chopping wood in the yard.
• Add some fresh parsley, finely chopped.
• Chop (up) the onions and carrots roughly.
• informal Laura had her hair chopped (= cut) yesterday.

Definition: A district is a small part of a city, county, state, or country.
Example: I live in a residential district of Seattle, Washington.
Cambridge Examples:
• the business district of New York
• the Lake District/the Peak District
• US the City of Malden School District
• UK South Cambridgeshire District Council

Definition: To endure something tough means to do or go through it.
Example: She had to endure her husband shouting all day long.
Cambridge Examples:
• We had to endure a nine-hour delay at the airport.
• She's already had to endure three painful operations on her leg.

Definition: To stir something means to mix it using something small, like a spoon.
Example: Mom stirred the batter until it was smooth.
Cambridge Examples:
• Stir the sauce gently until it begins to boil.
• Stir the egg yolks into the mixture.
• She paused to stir some milk into her coffee.
• Slowly add the flour, stirring until completely blended.

Definition: To tap something is to hit it lightly.
Example: He tapped the keys of the keyboard to write a short word.
Cambridge Examples:
• The branches tapped against the window.
• I could hear him tapping his fingers on the desk.
• I was tapping my feet (= hitting the floor gently with my feet) to the music.
• Someone tapped me on the shoulder.

Definition: When something is tremendous, it is very large.
Example: The Earth's oceans are filled with a tremendous amount of water.
Cambridge Examples:
• They were making a tremendous amount of noise last night.
• She's been a tremendous (= very great) help to me over the last few months.
• You won? That's tremendous!

Definition: When something is underneath something else, it is below or lower than it.
Example: The roots of a tree are located underneath the ground.
Cambridge Examples:
• The tunnel goes right underneath the city.
• They found a bomb underneath the car.
• Underneath that shy exterior, she's actually a very warm person.
• He was wearing a garish T-shirt underneath his shirt.

Definition: A worm is a small animal with a long, thin body.
Example: worms are often used to help catch fish.
Cambridge Examples: • The kiwi bird eats worms, other invertebrates, and berries.

Definition: To abandon something is to leave it forever or for a long time.
Example: The old room had been abandoned years before.
Cambridge Examples:
• We had to abandon the car.
• By the time the rebel troops arrived, the village had already been abandoned.
• As a baby he was abandoned by his mother.
• We were sinking fast, and the captain gave the order to abandon ship.

Definition: If someone is ambitious, they want to be rich or successful.
Example: Kendra had to be ambitious to get into medical school.
Cambridge Examples:
• an ambitious young lawyer
• He's very ambitious for his children (= he wants them to be successful).

Definition: When a dog barks, it makes a short, loud noise.
Example: The dog barked loudly and frighteningly.
Cambridge Examples: • They heard a dog barking outside.

Definition: A bay is an area near the ocean where the land goes inward.
Example: The Golden Gate Bridge crosses San Francisco bay.
Cambridge Examples:
• We sailed into a beautiful, secluded bay.
• San Francisco Bay
• the Bay of Naples

Definition: If someone is brilliant, they are very smart.
Example: My younger sister is brilliant for someone her age.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her mother was a brilliant scientist.
• He gave a brilliant performance.
• The idea was quite brilliant.
• She seemed to have a brilliant career ahead of her (= was likely to be extremely successful).

Definition: Your chin is the hard part at the bottom of your face.
Example: Luke pointed to the hair on his chin.
Cambridge Examples:
• To keep the helmet in position, fasten the strap beneath the chin.
• She sat behind the table, her chin resting in her hands.

Definition: A complaint is something you say to tell people that you don't like something.
Example: Mom said she didn't want to hear my brother's complaints.
Cambridge Examples:
• We've received a complaint from one of our listeners about offensive language.
• I've made a complaint (= formally complained) to the police about the noise.
• [ + that ] We've had complaints that you've been playing your radio too loud.
• Do you have any grounds for complaint (= reason to formally complain)?

Definition: When someone is deaf, they cannot hear.
Example: Susan was born deaf.
Cambridge Examples: • He's been totally/partially deaf since birth.

Definition: To be enthusiastic about something is to be excited by or interested in it.
Example: The man was enthusiastic  about his job.
Cambridge Examples: • You don't seem very enthusiastic about the party - don't you want to go tonight?

Definition: An expedition is a long trip, usually to a place very far away.
Example: They got into their spaceship to begin their expedition.
Cambridge Examples:
• We're going on a shopping expedition on Saturday.
• Scott died while he was on an expedition to the Antarctic in 1912.

Definition: To be loyal to something or someone is to agree to always help them.
Example: The three friends are very loyal to each other.
Cambridge Examples:
• Jack has been a loyal worker in this company for almost 50 years.
• When all her other friends deserted her, Steve remained loyal.
• She's very loyal to her friends.

Definition: The mayor is the person in charge of a city.
Example: The mayor of my hometown is quite a powerful speaker.
Cambridge Examples:
• The prime minister met many civic leaders, including the mayor and the leaders of the immigrant communities.
• We need a mayor who is tough enough to clean up this town.
• The mayor has promised to cleanse the city of drug dealers.
• The mayor and the city council are anxious to avoid getting entangled in the controversy.
• They were flattered to be invited to dinner by the mayor.

Definition: If someone is overweight, they are heavier than is allowed
Example: Roger eats too much, so now he's overweight.
Cambridge Examples: • If your luggage is overweight, you have to pay extra.

Definition: To restore something is to put it back the way it was.
Example: Victor restored the old car.
Cambridge Examples:
• The badly neglected paintings have all been carefully restored.
• After a week in bed, she was fully restored to health (= she felt healthy again).
• The former leader was today restored to power in the first free elections for 20 years.

Definition: To rub something is to push on it and move your hand back and forth.
Example: Mom's feet were sore, so she rubbed them.
Cambridge Examples:
• She yawned and rubbed her eyes sleepily.
• He rubbed (at) the stain on his trousers and made it worse.
• We rubbed some polish into the surface of the wood.
• She gently rubbed the ointment in.
• First rub the baking tray well with butter.
• [ + obj + adj ] Alice rubbed the blackboard clean for the teacher.
• Your cat keeps on rubbing itself (up) against my leg.
• She was rubbing her hands (together) at the thought of winning.
• The branches rubbed against each other in the wind.
• The chair legs have rubbed holes in the carpet.
• My new shoes are rubbing (against/on my toe) and now I've got blisters.
• These marks will never rub off (= be cleaned off).
• Alice rubbed the sums off (= cleaned them off) the blackboard for the teacher.

Definition: Your senses are how you see, taste, hear, feel and smell.
Example: It would be hard to live without your five senses.
Cambridge Examples:
• With her excellent sense of smell, she could tell if you were a smoker from the other side of the room.
• My cold is so bad I've lost my sense of smell/taste (= I can't smell/taste anything).

Definition: An anniversary is a day that celebrates something from the past.
Example: My parents went out to eat for their wedding anniversary.
Cambridge Examples:
• We always celebrate our wedding anniversary with dinner in an expensive restaurant.
• Tomorrow is the 30th anniversary of the revolution.

Definition: To be ashamed is to feel upset because you did something wrong or bad.
Example: He was ashamed when he found out that I knew about his past.
Cambridge Examples:
• You've got nothing to be ashamed of.
• She ought to be thoroughly ashamed of herself - talking to her mother like that!
• [ + to infinitive ] He was ashamed to admit to his mistake.
• [ + that ] I was ashamed that I'd made so little effort.
• I'm ashamed to be seen with you when you behave so badly!
• I felt so ashamed of myself for making such a fuss.
• I'm so ashamed of you (= embarrassed to be connected with you)!

Definition: To burst is to suddenly break open or apart.
Example: The bomb bursted over the city.
Cambridge Examples:
• I hate it when balloons burst.
• Suddenly the door burst open (= opened suddenly and forcefully) and police officers rushed in.
• The river was threatening to burst its banks.
• figurative humorous If I eat any more cake I'll burst (= I cannot eat anything else)!

Definition: If something is elegant, it is very fancy and pleasing.
Example: In Japan, women wear elegant kimonos on special occasions.
Cambridge Examples:
• an elegant woman
• a very elegant suit
• an elegant dining room

Definition: A needle is a small, sharp piece of metal that you use to make or fix clothes.
Example: I used a needle to fix the hole in my pants.
Cambridge Examples:
• a needle and thread
• Here, your eyes are better than mine - could you thread (= put thread through) this needle for me?

Definition: To sew means to put pieces of cloth together using string.
Example: I learned to sew when I was a little girl.
Cambridge Examples:
• My grandmother taught me to sew.
• I made this skirt just by sewing two pieces of material together.
• He sewed the badge neatly onto his uniform.

Definition: A shed is a small building where you store things like tools.
Example: We have a small shed in the backyard for storage.
Cambridge Examples:
• a tool/storage shed
• UK a garden/bicycle shed

Definition: To boast is to talk about how good you are.
Example: We all became tired of listening to him boast about himself all day.

Definition: To bounce is to move something up and away from a surface after hitting it.
Example: Owen bounced the ball on the ground.
Cambridge Examples:
• The ball bounced off the goalpost and into the net.
• She bounced the ball quickly.
• Her bag bounced (= moved up and down) against her side as she walked.
• The children had broken the bed by bouncing (= jumping up and down) on it.
• He bounced the baby (= lifted it up and down) on his knee.
• figurative Television pictures from all over the world are bounced off satellites (= are sent to and returned from them).

Definition: To crawl is to move slowly on your hands and knees.
Example: The baby crawled across the floor.
Cambridge Examples:
• The child crawled across the floor.
• Megan has just learned to crawl.
• The injured soldier crawled to safety.
• He had to crawl along a ledge and get in through a window.

Definition: To defeat someone is to beat them in a game or battle.
Example: The champion defeated the challenger in the boxing match.
Cambridge Examples:
• Napoleon was defeated by the Duke of Wellington at the battle of Waterloo.
• They defeated the Italian team and reached the final.

Definition: To nod is to move your head up and down.
Example: I nodded my head as I listened to the song.
Cambridge Examples:
• Many people in the audience nodded in agreement.
• When I suggested a walk, Elena nodded enthusiastically.
• She looked up and nodded for me to come in.

Definition: An opponent is someone who fights against you.
Example: On the field, our opponents were too good for us.
Cambridge Examples: • In the second game, her opponent hurt her leg and had to retire.

Definition: When a part of your body is sore, it hurts.
Example: After lifting the heavy box, Mona's back was sore.
Cambridge Examples:
• All the dust has made my eyes sore.
• I've got a sore back.
• My feet were sore with all the walking.

Definition: To quarrel is to argue or fight.
Example: Billy quarreled with his wife about buying a new house.
Cambridge Examples:
• What did you quarrel about/over?
• She quarrelled with everyone in the village.

Definition: absence is the state of something being away.
Example: There is an absence of sand in the hourglass.
Cambridge Examples:
• A new manager was appointed during/in her absence.
• She has had repeated absences from work this year.

Definition: If you say something aloud, you say it so that others can hear you.
Example: My father often reads stories aloud to me and my sister.
Cambridge Examples:
• He read her letter aloud to the rest of the family.
• People are starting to wonder aloud (= question publicly) whether the economic reforms have gone too far.

Definition: If someone is bald, they have no hair.
Example: My oldest brother is bald.
Cambridge Examples: • At 20 he was already going bald.

Definition: divorce is an event in which a marriage is ended.
Example: divorce rates have increased in the past twenty years.
Cambridge Examples:
• The last I heard they were getting a divorce.
• Divorce is on the increase.
• Ellie wants a divorce.
• What are the chances of a marriage ending in divorce?

Definition: You use nowhere to say that a place or thing does not exist.
Example: Unfortunately, water was nowhere to be found.
Cambridge Examples:
• These young people have nowhere (else) to go.
• Nowhere does the article mention the names of the people involved.

Definition: relief is a feeling you get when something bad or challenging ends.
Example: I felt a sense of relief when I heard the good news.
Cambridge Examples:
• [ + to infinitive ] It was such a relief to hear that Marta was found safe and well.
• After the exam, I felt an incredible sense of relief.
• "James can't come tonight." "Well, that's a relief!"
• to seek/find/provide relief from the heat/cold/pain/noise

Definition: If something is urgent, it is important and needs to be done now.
Example: He had to leave now; it was urgent.
Cambridge Examples:
• He's got to sign that paper - will you tell him it's urgent?
• The most urgent thing in a fire is to make sure everyone is out of the building.
• Many people are in urgent need of food and water.

Definition: To vanish is to go away suddenly.
Example: All the passengers vanished from the train station.
Cambridge Examples:
• The child vanished while on her way home from school.
• We ran out after the thief, but he had vanished into thin air (= had completely disappeared).
• Cheap rural housing is vanishing in the south of the country.

Definition: If someone is dishonest, they do not tell the truth.
Example: She was being dishonest when she copied the answers from his test.
Cambridge Examples:
• a dishonest lawyer
• a dishonest way of making money
• morally dishonest
• intellectually dishonest
• He's been dishonest in his dealings with us/about his past.

Definition: If something is fatal, it causes death.
Example: They passed away in a fatal car crash.
Cambridge Examples:
• This illness is fatal in almost all cases.
• the fatal shooting of an unarmed 15-year-old

Definition: If someone is impatient, they are not able to wait for things.
Example: Bob was so impatient that he could barely wait for the light to turn green.
Cambridge Examples:
• He's a good teacher, but inclined to be a bit impatient with slow learners.
• You'd be hopeless taking care of children - you're far too impatient!

Definition: A leaf is the flat green thing on trees or bushes.
Example: In the fall, the leaves on the trees change colors.
Cambridge Examples:
• a palm leaf
• autumn leaves
• He was raking up leaves in his garden.

Definition: patience is the ability to wait for something without becoming upset.
Example: Sue's patience was rewarded by catching her very first fish.
Cambridge Examples:
• You have to have such a lot of patience when you're dealing with kids.
• In the end I lost my patience and shouted at her.
• He's a good teacher, but he doesn't have much patience with the slower pupils.
• Making small-scale models takes/requires a great deal of patience.
• Their youngest son was beginning to try my patience (= annoy me).
• Patience - they'll be here soon!

Definition: A pond is a very small area of water.
Example: The ducks swam in the pond.
Cambridge Examples: • a duck pond

Definition: If you are deliberate, you do something on purpose.
Example: Bernie made a deliberate attempt to injure Andy.
Cambridge Examples:
• a deliberate attack/insult/lie
• We made a deliberate decision to live apart for a while.

Definition: When something explodes, it blows up.
Example: My new radio exploded when I plugged it in.
Cambridge Examples:
• A bomb exploded at one of the capital's busiest railway stations this morning.
• He was driving so fast that his car tyre exploded.

Definition: To fasten something is to close it or put it in the correct place.
Example: Elizabeth fastened her seat belt.
Cambridge Examples:
• Make sure your seat belt is securely fastened.
• This shirt fastens at the back.

Definition: A kit is a set of all the things needed to do something.
Example: Is there a first aid kit in your office?
Cambridge Examples:
• a first-aid/tool kit
• a pregnancy-testing kit

Definition: A scent is a smell.
Example: Julie enjoyed the scent of the flowers.
Cambridge Examples: • the scent of roses

Definition: steel is a shiny gray metal.
Example: The new apartment building was made with steel.
Cambridge Examples:
• steel girders/rods/struts
• a steel helmet
• a steel-plated army truck

Definition: When a person is bitter, they are upset with someone or a situation.
Example: He was extremely bitter when his computer crashed.
Cambridge Examples:
• a bitter fight/argument
• bitter recriminations
• He gave me a bitter look.

Definition: A bullet is a small metal object that is shot out of guns.
Example: bullets come in different sizes for different guns.
Cambridge Examples: • A bullet had lodged in the boy's leg.

Definition: The devil is a powerful evil spirit in some religions.
Example: The church promised protection from the devil.
Cambridge Examples: • The devil was painted with horns and cloven hoofs.

Definition: A fountain is a stream of water that is forced up into the air through a small hole, especially for decorative effect, or the structure in a lake or pool from which this flow.
Example: There was a beautiful fountain in the middle of the park.
Cambridge Examples:
• There was a picture of the Trevi fountain on the front of the book.
• They also sell garden ornaments such as statues and fountains.

Definition: A harbor is an area of water next to the coast, often protected from the ocean by a thick wall, where ships and boats can shelter.
Example: There were a few small boats in the harbor.
Cambridge Examples: • Our hotel room overlooked a pretty little fishing harbor.

Definition: A port is a place where ships stop to load and unload things.
Example: The ship was being loaded with materials at the port.
Cambridge Examples:
• a naval/fishing/container port
• We had a good view of all the ships coming into/leaving port.

Definition: To sweat means to lose liquid from the body through the skin.
Example: Whenever I workout, I sweat quite a bit.
Cambridge Examples:
• It was so hot when we arrived in Tripoli that we started to sweat as soon as we got off the plane.
• The prisoners were sweating with fear.
• informal I was so afraid, I was sweating like a pig (= sweating a lot).

Definition: A voyage is a long journey made on a boat or an aircraft.
Example: The astronauts took off on a long voyage to the moon.
Cambridge Examples:
• He was a young sailor on his first sea voyage.
• figurative The first year of a loving relationship is a voyage (= period) of discovery.

Definition: To assure someone is to tell them something is true to make them less worried.
Example: He assure the boss that the building would be done on time.
Cambridge Examples:
• The unions assured the new owners of the workers' loyalty to the company.
• [ + speech ] "Don't worry, your car will be ready tomorrow," the mechanic assured him.
• [ + (that) ] She assured him (that) the car would be ready the next day.
• The prime minister assured the electorate (that) taxes would not be increased after the election.
• You can rest assured (= feel confident) that I shall be there as promised.

Definition: To bleed is to lose blood.
Example: If you are not careful, you will cut your finger and bleed.
Cambridge Examples:
• Your arm is bleeding.
• He was bleeding heavily.

Definition: A departure is the act of leaving a place.
Example: They were excited about their departure back home.
Cambridge Examples:
• There are several departures (= buses, trains, or aircraft leaving) for Paris every day.
• Our departure was delayed because of bad weather.
• departure time

Definition: If someone is impolite, they are rude.
Example: Roger is impolite to everyone he meets.
Cambridge Examples:
• impolite language/behaviour
• It is impolite to point at people.
• It would be impolite to leave in the middle of the band's set.

Definition: To kneel is to put one or both knees on the ground.
Example: Daryl got down on one knee and asked Nina to marry him.
Cambridge Examples:
• She knelt (down) beside the child.
• He knelt in front of the altar and prayed.

Definition: If something is massive, it is very big.
Example: The wheels on his truck were massive.
Cambridge Examples:
• They have a massive house.
• She died after taking a massive overdose of drugs.
• If the drought continues, deaths will occur on a massive scale.

Definition: To panic is to feel so nervous or afraid that you cannot think clearly.
Example: Everyone panicked when the house caught on fire.
Cambridge Examples:
• Don't panic! Everything will be okay.
• The sound of gunfire panicked the crowd.
• The boss always panics over/about the budget every month.

Definition: A priority is something that is more important than other things.
Example: My priority is to get good grades in school.
Cambridge Examples:
• The management did not seem to consider office safety to be a priority.
• My first/top priority is to find somewhere to live.
• You have to learn to get your priorities right/straight (= decide which are the most important jobs or problems and deal with them first).
• Repairing the plumbing is a priority task (= more important than other jobs).
• Banks normally give priority to large businesses when deciding on loans (= they deal with them first because they consider them most important).
• Official business requirements obviously take/have priority over personal requests (= official business matters will be dealt with first).

Definition: An affair is an event or a thing that happened.
Example: My wife and I attended a formal affair over the weekend.
Cambridge Examples: • The party turned out to be a quiet affair.

Definition: If someone is cheerful, they are happy or feel good.
Example: The children were cheerful because they didn't have to go to school.
Cambridge Examples:
• He's usually fairly cheerful.
• You're in a cheerful mood this morning.
• She manages to stay cheerful (= happy and positive) despite everything.

Definition: To exploit something is to use it for greedy reasons rather than good reasons. To take advantage of.
Example: The company exploits their workers and makes them stay 12 hours a day.
Cambridge Examples: • We need to make sure that we exploit our resources as fully as possible.

Definition: A nut is a hard seed or fruit that comes from some trees and bushes.
Example: To eat a nut, first you have to crack its shell.
Cambridge Examples:
• a Brazil/cashew nut
• Sprinkle some roasted chopped nuts on top.

Definition: When a fruit is ripe, it is ready to be eaten.
Example: The cherries were nice and ripe.
Cambridge Examples: • Those bananas aren't ripe yet - they're still green.

Definition: A routine is a way of doing things that is the same every time.
Example: My father's daily routine includes shaving right before breakfast.
Cambridge Examples:
• There's no set/fixed routine at work - every day is different.
• Most companies insure property and equipment against damage or theft as a matter of routine.

Definition: A theft is a criminal act that involves someone stealing something.
Example: The theft of his TV took place when he was at work.
Cambridge Examples:
• Unfortunately, we have had several thefts in the building recently.
• Shoplifting is theft.

Definition: journalism is the work of collecting the news to put in newspapers or on TV.
Example: Before becoming a teacher, she worked in journalism.
Cambridge Examples:
• The ethics of journalism are much debated.
• He decided to forsake politics for journalism.
• My son's planning to go into journalism.
• He claims that a lot of journalism is meretricious and superficial.
• She has a nice turn of phrase which should serve her well in journalism.

Definition: A jury is a group of people that listen to a trial and say if someone is guilty.
Example: The jury listened closely to the attorney before they made their decision.
Cambridge Examples:
• members of the jury
• The jury has/have been unable to return a verdict (= reach a decision).
• Police officers aren't usually allowed to be/sit/serve on a jury.

Definition: justice is fairness in the way that you treat other people.
Example: People turn to the court system when they are seeking justice.
Cambridge Examples:
• There's no justice in the world when people can be made to suffer like that.
• The winner has been disqualified for cheating, so justice has been done (= a fair situation has been achieved).

Definition: liberty is freedom to do what you want.
Example: To many people, the Statue of liberty is a symbol of freedom.
Cambridge Examples:
• For most citizens, liberty means the freedom to practise their religious or political beliefs.
• Hundreds of political prisoners are to be given their liberty (= released from prison).
• Of the ten men who escaped this morning from Dartmoor Prison, only two are still at liberty (= free or not yet caught).

Definition: If someone or something is literary, it is involved with literature in some way.
Example: He worked hard to create a successful literary career.
Cambridge Examples:
• a literary critic
• literary prizes
• a literary style

Definition: A pharmacy is a place where medicine is sold.
Example: My mother sells medicine to people at the pharmacy.
Cambridge Examples:
• A typical independent pharmacy gets 92% of its income from prescriptions.
• He got his medicines in the pharmacy of a Manhattan hospital.

Definition: A pill is a small object that has medicine inside.
Example: She took a pill for her headache.
Cambridge Examples:
• a sleeping pill
• a vitamin pill
• My mother takes three or four pills a day.
• Jamie's always had trouble swallowing pills.

Definition: A punishment is something that one must endure for any wrongdoing.
Example: He was given a punishment for being rude to the teacher.
Cambridge Examples:
• Many people think that the death penalty is too severe a punishment for any crime.
• formal It was always our father who administered/meted out punishments.
• Drink-driving is one case in which severe punishment seems to work as a deterrent.

Definition: If someone is sensible, they make good decisions.
Example: It was sensible for her to save some money each month.
Cambridge Examples:
• a sensible answer/approach/compromise/option
• a sensible person
• I think the sensible thing to do is call and ask for directions.
• It would be sensible to take an umbrella.

Definition: affection is a feeling of liking someone or something.
Example: Amanda has a lot of affection for her little sister Sarah.
Cambridge Examples:
• She felt no affection for the child.
• He had a deep affection for his aunt.

Definition: An agency is a business or service set up to act for others.
Example: I went to a travel agency to help me arrange a flight home.
Cambridge Examples: • an advertising/employment/estate/travel agency

Definition: fate is a power that causes some things to happen.
Example: Some people believe that a person's hand can tell their fate.
Cambridge Examples:
• We want to decide our own fate.
• His fate is now in the hands of the jury.
• The disciples were terrified that they would suffer/meet the same fate as Jesus.

Definition: If someone is miserable, they are very unhappy.
Example: He was miserable after his dog died.
Cambridge Examples: • She's miserable living on her own.

Definition: If something is shallow, it is not deep.
Example: The kids were playing in the shallow water.
Cambridge Examples:
• The stream was fairly shallow so we were able to walk across it.
• She told her children to stay in the shallow end (of the swimming pool).
• Fry the onions in a shallow pan.
• These beech trees have shallow roots (= roots which do not go very deep into the ground).

Definition: A slope is ground that is not flat.
Example: The slope to the top of the mountain was very steep.
Cambridge Examples: • The roof is at a slope (= at an angle to a horizontal surface) of 30°.

Definition: sympathy is a feeling of being sad for another person.
Example: I felt sympathy for my sister so I got her a ballon to cheer her up.
Cambridge Examples:
• The president has sent a message of sympathy to the relatives of the dead soldiers.
• I don't have much sympathy for her - I think she's brought her troubles on herself.

Definition: To wander is to walk without going to a certain place.
Example: The boys like to wander in the woods and look at birds.
Cambridge Examples:
• We spent the morning wandering around the old part of the city.
• She was found several hours later, wandering the streets, lost.
• He was here a minute ago but he's wandered off somewhere.

Definition: A cliff is a high and often flat wall of rock.
Example: The wolf stood at the cliff and howled.
Cambridge Examples:
• Keep away from the edge of the cliff - you might fall.
• the cliff edge

Definition: A flame is part of fire.
Example: The torch was filled with yellow and orange flames.
Cambridge Examples:
• The flames grew larger as the fire spread.
• The car flipped over and burst into flames (= started burning immediately).
• When the fire engine arrived the house was already in flames (= burning).

Definition: independence is the state of being free from the control of others.
Example: After leaving home, Sophia had a great feeling of independence.
Cambridge Examples: • It's important that parents should allow their children some independence.

Definition: An invasion is an attack by a group from another country.
Example: In Korea, walls were built around cities to protect them from invasions.
Cambridge Examples: • They were planning to mount an invasion of the north of the country.

Definition: lightning is the bright light seen during a storm.
Example: The lightning flashed above the water.
Cambridge Examples:
• thunder and lightning
• a flash/bolt of lightning
• That tree was struck by lightning.
• She changed her clothes with lightning speed (= extremely quickly).

Definition: A rebel is a person who flights the government in order to change it.
Example: The rebel had enough of the government's unfair polices.
Cambridge Examples:
• The rebels took over the capital and set up a new government.
• rebel troops/fighters

Definition: A revolution is a change to the political system by a group of people.
Example: The revolution in Russia led to the creation of the Soviet Union.
Cambridge Examples:
• The French Revolution changed France from a monarchy to a republic.
• The country seems to be heading towards revolution.

Definition: If something is steep, then its slope or angle rises or falls sharply.
Example: He rode his bike up the steep hill to reach the top.
Cambridge Examples:
• a steep slope
• It's a steep climb to the top of the mountain, but the view is worth it.
• The castle is set on a steep hill/hillside.

Definition: thunder is the loud noise heard during a storm.
Example: The sound of the thunder startled me.
Cambridge Examples:
• a clap of thunder
• thunder and lightning

Definition: A bench is a long seat for two or more people.
Example: Most parks have benches for citizens to relax upon.
Cambridge Examples: • a park bench (= a seat in a public garden)

Definition: horror is a feeling of being very afraid or shocked.
Example: The audience screamed in horror when the ghost appeared in the movie.
Cambridge Examples:
• The crowd cried out in horror as the car burst into flames.
• The thought of speaking in front of so many people fills me with horror.
• I then realized to my absolute horror, that I had forgotten the present.
• What the book does convey very successfully is the horror of war.

Definition: An incident is an event that is usually not pleasant.
Example: Mr. Wilson had an incident where he became sick and had to leave.
Cambridge Examples:
• an isolated/serious/unfortunate incident
• A youth was seriously injured in a shooting incident on Saturday night.

Definition: mist is water that you can see in the air or on a surface.
Example: The forest was covered with mist.
Cambridge Examples:
• The mountain villages seem to be permanently shrouded in mist.
• The early-morning mist soon lifted/cleared.

Definition: An object is an inanimate thing that you can see or touch.
Example: The shopping cart was filled with objects.
Cambridge Examples:
• a solid/material/physical object
• a collection of precious objects
• Several people reported seeing a strange object in the sky.

Definition: When a female is pregnant, she is going to have a baby.
Example: The pregnant woman was shopping for baby clothes.
Cambridge Examples:
• She's five and a half months pregnant.
• My mother stopped smoking when she became pregnant.
• He believes that men who get (= make) young girls pregnant should be severely punished.
• My sister is pregnant with twins.

Definition: rage is a very angry feeling.
Example: The chef was filled with rage when his helpers ruined the meal.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her sudden towering rages were terrifying.
• I was frightened because I had never seen him in such a rage before.
• He flew into a fit of rage over the smallest mistake.

Definition: revenge is what you do to hurt or punish someone who hurts you.
Example: He broke his sister's doll as revenge after she lost his favorite book.
Cambridge Examples:
• She took/got/exacted (her) revenge on him for leaving her by smashing up his car.
• He is believed to have been shot by a rival gang in revenge for the shootings last week.

Definition: To sigh is to breathe out loudly and show that you are tired or sad.
Example: Molly sighed when she looked at all the information she had to research.
Cambridge Examples:
• She sighed deeply and sat down.
• [ + speech ] "I wish he was here," she sighed (= she said with a sigh).

Definition: If something is beneath something else, it is under it.
Example: The largest part of an iceberg lies beneath the waterline.
Cambridge Examples:
• Jaime hid the letter beneath a pile of papers.
• We huddled together for warmth beneath the blankets.
• After weeks at sea, it was wonderful to feel firm ground beneath our feet once more.
• Emma was so tired and hungry that her legs were beginning to give way beneath her (= she was about to fall over).

Definition: dawn is the time of day when the sun rises.
Example: At dawn, the sun gently rose over the farm.
Cambridge Examples:
• We woke at dawn.
• We left as dawn was breaking (= starting).
• We left at the break of dawn.

Definition: If you are dissatisfied, you are not happy with something.
Example: I was dissatisfied with their decision to work on Sunday.
Cambridge Examples: • If you're dissatisfied with the service, why don't you complain to the hotel manager?

Definition: When something is done with ease, it is not hard to do.
Example: The monkey climbed the tree with ease.
Cambridge Examples:
• She won the 400 metre race with ease.
• The doors are extra-wide for ease of access (= so that people can get in without difficulty).

Definition: When something is evident, it is easy to see or understand.
Example: It was evident from the look on his face that he was unhappy.
Cambridge Examples:
• The full extent of the damage only became evident the following morning.
• From the smell it was evident that the drains had been blocked for several days.
• Harry's courage during his illness was evident to everyone.
• Her love for him was evident in all that she did.

Definition: When something is magnificent, it is beautiful and grand.
Example: The man gave  his wife a pair of magnificent diamond earrings.
Cambridge Examples:
• a magnificent view
• a magnificent piece of writing
• They live in a magnificent Tudor house.

Definition: A pile is a large group of things on top of one another.
Example: The pile of cups was beginning to tilt.
Cambridge Examples:
• a pile of books
• a pile of dirty clothes

Definition: To seize something means to grab it quickly or strongly.
Example: The man seized as much money as he could before anyone could see him.
Cambridge Examples:
• I seized his arm and made him turn to look at me.
• He seized the chance/opportunity of a free flight with both hands (= with eagerness or enthusiasm).

Definition: To squeeze something means to press it together and hold it tightly.
Example: When Clara saw her cat, she gave it a big squeeze.
Cambridge Examples:
• Cut the lemon in half and squeeze the juice into the bowl.
• As she waited to go into the exam, he squeezed her hand (= pressed it affectionately with his hand) and wished her good luck.
• Once he had finished cleaning the floor, he squeezed the cloth out.
• He reloaded the gun, took aim, and then squeezed (= pulled back) the trigger.
• figurative The studio is using all sorts of marketing tricks to squeeze as much profit from the movie as they can.

Definition: When something is terrific, it is very good.
Example: My youngest daughter is a terrific painter.
Cambridge Examples:
• a terrific opportunity
• You look terrific!

Definition: When something is vital, it is necessary for life.
Example: The heart is a vital organ.
Cambridge Examples:
• A strong opposition is vital to a healthy democracy.
• She had found out some information of vital importance.
• The kidney plays a vital role/part in the removal of waste products from the blood.
• [ + that ] It's absolutely vital that you do exactly as I say.
• [ + to infinitive ] It is vital to get medical supplies to the area as soon as possible.

Definition: If someone is astonished, they are very surprised or shocked.
Example: I was astonished when he pulled the live rabbit out of his hat.
Cambridge Examples:
• [ + to infinitive ] I was astonished to see Miriam there.
• They looked astonished when I announced I was pregnant.
• The doctors were astonished at the speed of her recovery.

Definition: To bang is to hit something to make a noise.
Example: The drummer banged on his drum as he marched in the parade.
Cambridge Examples:
• She banged her fist angrily on the table.
• Outside a door was banging in the wind.
• He could hear someone banging at the door.
• I could hear her in the kitchen banging about (= doing things noisily).

Definition: To leak is to let a liquid or gas pass through a flaw.
Example: The pipe leaks from many places.
Cambridge Examples:
• Water was leaking from the pipe.
• Oil leaked out of the car.
• The car leaked oil all over the drive.
• The tin was leaking.

Definition: When something is stiff, it is hard to move.
Example: The bird was standing on the tree's stiff branch.
Cambridge Examples:
• stiff cardboard
• a stiff collar
• His clothes were stiff with dried mud.
• This hair spray has made my hair stiff.
• Mix the powder and water into a stiff paste.

Definition: To stroke is to move a hand over something or someone.
Example: She stroked her cheek to see if there was something on it.
Cambridge Examples:
• Stroke the dog if you want, he won't bite.
• She lovingly stroked Chris's face with the tips of her fingers.

Definition: When something is tragic, it is connected with death and suffering.
Example: The airplane crashed in a tragic accident.
Cambridge Examples:
• His friends were deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news of his death.
• The bomb explosion resulted in a tragic loss of life.
• Hospital authorities admitted that a tragic mistake/error had been made.
• It is tragic that the theatre has had to close.

Definition: A circus is a traveling show with animals and people.
Example: I like to go to the circus to see the animals do tricks.
Cambridge Examples:
• She ran away to join the circus.
• The horses trotted into the circus ring (= the large circle, with seats all around, in which a circus performs).
• The children loved being taken to the circus.

Definition: A dose is a certain amount of medicine that you take at one time.
Example: My mother gave me a dose of medicine before I went to bed.
Cambridge Examples:
• a high/low dose
• a dose of penicillin
• The label says to take one dose three times a day.
• 20 or 30 of these pills would be a lethal dose (= enough to kill you).

Definition: The extent of something is how large, important, or serious it is.
Example: He ate to such an extent that he bacame overweight.
Cambridge Examples:
• From the top of the Empire State Building, you can see the full extent of Manhattan (= the area it covers).
• We don't yet know the extent of his injuries (= how bad his injuries are).
• Rosie's teacher was impressed by the extent of her knowledge (= how much she knew).
• The River Nile is over 6,500 6,5000 kilometres in extent (= length).

Definition: A headline is the title of a newspaper story.
Example: The headline on the front page was about the economy.
