• The news of his death was splashed in headlines across all the newspapers.
• the eight o'clock headlines

Definition: When something is informal, it is not official.
Example: They had an informal meeting to talk about their experiences.
Cambridge Examples:
• The two groups agreed to hold an informal meeting.
• Alliances among small businesses are often informal arrangements, such as two companies teaming up for a marketing event.

Definition: To inquire about something is to ask about it.
Example: Dad called to inquire about the price of tickets for the show.
Cambridge Examples:
• Shall I inquire about the price of tickets?
• [ + question word ] She called to inquire when her car would be ready.
• [ + speech ] "Where are we going?" he inquired politely.

Definition: A portrait is a painting or photograph of someone.
Example: I saw many religious portraits when I went to the museum.
Cambridge Examples:
• She's commissioned an artist to paint her portrait/paint a portrait of her.
• a portrait gallery
• a portrait painter

Definition: To steer something is to control where it goes.
Example: He steered the go-cart around the track.
Cambridge Examples:
• She carefully steered the car around the potholes.
• This car is very easy to steer.

Definition: A stripe is a thick line.
Example: The flag of the United States has red and white stripes.
Cambridge Examples: • a blue tie with gray stripes

Definition: To ban something is to not let people do it.
Example: Smoking is banned in this building.
Cambridge Examples:
• The film was banned (= the government prevented it from being shown) in several countries.
• [ + from + -ing verb ] She was banned from driving for two years.

Definition: If you are cautious, you are careful in a dangerous situation.
Example: Be very cautious as you stack those boxes.
Cambridge Examples: • He's a cautious driver.

Definition: To confess something is to say that you did it.
Example: He confessed that he was responsible for choosing the winning story.
Cambridge Examples:
• [ + that ] She confessed to her husband that she had sold her wedding ring.
• He confessed to sleeping/having slept through most of the movie.

• [ + (that) ] I have to confess (that) when I first met Reece I didn't think he was very bright.
• It was all very confusing, I must confess.

Definition: A cottage is a small, old house in the countryside.
Example: My aunt lives in a pretty cottage in the mountains.
Cambridge Examples:
• They live in an idyllic country/thatched cottage, with roses around the door.
• We rented a little beach cottage on the North Caroline coast.

Definition: daytime is the time of the day when the sky is light.
Example: I only allowed my kids to play outside in the daytime.
Cambridge Examples:
• I tend to sleep in/during the daytime and study at night.
• a regular daytime job
• a daytime phone number
• daytime television

Definition: If you are desperate, you feel that you have no hope and are ready to do anything to change the bad situation you are in
Example: I'm desperate to find a new job.
Cambridge Examples:
• The doctors made one last desperate attempt/effort to save the boy's life.
• Desperate measures are needed to deal with the growing drug problem.
• They made a desperate plea for help.
Explanation:
Also very serious or bad [C2]:

a desperate shortage of food/supplies

Definition: If something fades, it gets quieter or darker.
Example: The piece of cloth I found was old and faded.
Cambridge Examples:
• If you hang your clothes out in the bright sun, they will fade.
• My suntan is already fading.
• They arrived home just as the light was fading (= as it was getting dark).
• The sun had faded the blue walls.

Definition: If a person or animal is fierce, they are angry or violent.
Example: Wolves are fierce animals. Do not disturb them.
Cambridge Examples:
• a fierce attack/battle
• Two men were shot during fierce fighting last weekend.

Definition: A prospect is a possibility that something will happen.
Example: He wakes up every morning with the prospect of having a good day.
Cambridge Examples:
• Is there any prospect of the weather improving?
• There seems little prospect of an end to the dispute.
• [ + that ] There's not much prospect that this war will be over soon.
• There's every prospect of success.

Definition: If something seldom happens, it doesn't happen very often.
Example: It seldom rains in southern Arizona.
Cambridge Examples:
• Now that we have a baby, we seldom get the chance to go to the cinema.
• formal Seldom do we receive any apology when mistakes are made.

Definition: To shave means to cut the hairs on your face with a sharp tool.
Example: My father shaves his face every day because he doesn't want a beard.
Cambridge Examples:
• John has to shave twice a day.
• I always shave my legs in the shower.
• Do you shave under your arms?
• When my dad shaved his beard (off), he looked ten years younger.

Definition: If you are terrified, you are extremely scared.
Example: When I saw the ghost, I was absolutely terrified!
Cambridge Examples:
• He huddled in the corner like a terrified child.
• I'm terrified of the dark.
• She's terrified (that) her mother might find out her secret.

Definition: baggage is the set of bags that people take with them when they travel.
Example: I'm taking several pieces of baggage with me on vacation.
Cambridge Examples:
• How many pieces of baggage do you have?
• We had to pay extra for our excess baggage (= our bags and suitcases that weighed more than was allowed).

Definition: A bulb is the glass part of an electric light.
Example: I had to change the light bulb in my bedroom.

Definition: cattle are cows and bulls, especially on a farm.
Example: The rancher's cattle were eating the grass in the field.
Cambridge Examples: • beef/dairy cattle

Definition: A lane is a small road.
Example: The lane passes directly in front of our house.
Cambridge Examples:
• He drives so fast along those narrow country lanes.
• I live at the end of Church Lane.

Definition: A parade is a celebration when groups of people walk in the same direction.
Example: There were many marching bands in the spring parade.

Definition: To scratch is to make small cuts with a claw or fingernail.
Example: I used a stick to scratch my back.
Cambridge Examples:

Definition: A widow is a woman whose husband has died.
Example: The widow had no children and was very lonely.
Cambridge Examples:
• He had some mercenary scheme to marry a wealthy widow.
• There once was a poor widow who had a beautiful daughter.
• It's a bloody disgrace that some war widows don't get a decent pension.
• A traditional Indian custom used to involve widows burning themselves alive on their husbands' funeral pyres.

Definition: To alter something means to make a small change to it.
Example: I altered the color of my nails to match my hair.
Cambridge Examples:
• We've had to alter some of our plans.
• Although the cost of making phone calls is going up, the charge for connecting to the internet will not alter.

Definition: If someone stands aside, they are on or to one side.

Definition: To collapse is to fall down suddenly.
Example: The tree collapsed right in front of our house.
Cambridge Examples:
• Thousands of buildings collapsed in the earthquake.

Definition: If something is disgusting, it is very unpleasant.

Definition: To envy someone is to wish that you had something that they have.
Example: Sally envied the happy couple.

• I envy her ability to talk to people she's never met before.

Definition: flour is a powder made from plants that is used to make foods like bread.
Example: I wanted to bake a pie, but I needed flour.

• Thicken the sauce with a little flour.

Definition: If you are jealous, you think someone might take something from you.

Definition: To wipe something is to slide a piece of cloth over it to clean it.

Definition: A wire is a thin string made out of metal.

Definition: An ambassador is a government worker who works in another country.
Example: The ambassador from Korea was in charge of the conference.

• She's a former ambassador to the United States.

Definition: To drag something means to pull it across the ground.
Example: The dog was dragging his owner down the street.

Definition: meanwhile means until something happens or while something is happening.

Definition: When something is precious, it is valuable and important.

• a precious moment/memory

Definition: A prejudice is an unfair opinion about someone before you get to know them.

• [ + that ] The campaign aims to dispel the prejudice that AIDS is confined to the homosexual community.

Definition: A rumor is a story that may not be true.

• The president has consistently denied the rumors.
• He denied all responsibility for the rumors that have been circulating.

Definition: If someone is suspicious of someone else, they do not trust that person.

Definition: A vase is an attractive container where people keep flowers.

• He drowned in a boating accident.

Definition: To travel via something means to travel through or using something.

Definition: A chemist is a scientist who works with chemicals.

Definition: An institution is an organization that works to help a city or group of people.
Example: Banks are vital institutions that businesses and people use every day.
Cambridge Examples:

Definition: To jog is to run slowly.
Example: He jogs every day so he can be healthier.

Definition: To postpone something is to make it happen later than planned.
Example: They postponed the meeting until Elena arrived.
Cambridge Examples:
• They decided to postpone their holiday until next year.

Definition: When a liquid splashes, it bursts and hits something.

• Water was splashing from a hole in the roof.

• She splashed her face with cold water.

Definition: If people are stubborn, they don't change their minds easily.
Example: Both of my parents are stubborn. They never give in to each other.
Cambridge Examples: • They have huge arguments because they're both so stubborn.

Definition: A suburb is a small part of a large city.
Example: I grew up in the suburbs only a few minutes outside of the city.
Cambridge Examples:
• Box Hill is a suburb of Melbourne.

Definition: The tide is the level of the water in the sea.
Example: The tide continued to crawl upon the beach little by little.
Cambridge Examples:
• high/low tide
• The tide is out/in.

Definition: A tragedy is a very sad event.
Example: It was a tragedy when his house was struck by lightning and burned.

• Hitler's invasion of Poland led to the tragedy of the Second World War.

• [ + (that) ] It's a tragedy (that) so many young people are unable to find jobs.

Definition: A bomb is an object that explodes and destroys large areas.
Example: The bomb will destroy anything that is near.
Cambridge Examples:
• A 100-pound bomb exploded/went off today, injuring three people.

Definition: A certificate is a document that says that something is true or happened.
Example: I was given a certificate after completing the computer course.

Definition: A circumstance is the condition that affect a situation, action, event etc
Example: There were many circumstances behind their success like hard work.
Cambridge Examples:

Definition: To cope with a difficult or stressful situation means to deal with it.
Example: He copes with work stress by exercising three or four times a week.

Definition: criticism is the act of saying that you don't like or approve of something.
Example: She had a lot of criticism about their new plan.
Cambridge Examples:

Definition: To gaze at something means to look at it for a long time.

Definition: To glance at something means to look at it quickly.
Example: She glanced behind her to see if he was looking at her.

Definition: grief is the feeling of deep sadness, usually when a person dies.
Example: The grief caused by losing her parents was very difficult for her.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her grief at her son's death was terrible.

• newspaper pictures of grief-stricken relatives

Definition: A groom is a man who is going to be married.

Cambridge Examples: • The bride and groom walked down the aisle together.

Definition: When something is nuclear, it relates to the division or joining of atoms.

• nuclear energy/power

Definition: A souvenir is something you buy to remind you of a place or event.
Example: I bought a Russian doll as a souvenir from my trip to Moscow.
Cambridge Examples:
• He bought a model of a red London bus as a souvenir of his trip to London.

Definition: If something or someone is delicate, they are easy to break or harm.
Example: You should hold the baby carefully because she's very delicate.

• Peaches have delicate skins which are easily bruised.

Definition: To emerge from something means to come out of it.
Example: The hand suddenly emerged from the grave.
Cambridge Examples: • She emerged from the sea, blue with cold.

Definition: A hook is a sharp curved piece of metal used for catching or holding things.
Example: The fish went after the sharp hook.
Cambridge Examples:
• a coat/picture hook
• a boat hook

Definition: laundry is clothes that have been or need to be washed.
Example: He folded the clean laundry and put the dirty laundry in a basket.
Cambridge Examples: • I've got to do (= wash) my laundry.

Definition: sleeves are the part of a shirt where your arms go.
Example: Ryan bought a new shirt with long sleeves to keep his arms warm.
Cambridge Examples:
• short/long sleeves
• The sleeves are too long for me.
• You'd better roll your sleeves up or you'll get them dirty.

Definition: A stain is a dirty mark that is difficult to clean.
Example: He had a red stain on the collar of his shirt.
Cambridge Examples:
• a blood/grass stain

Definition: To swear means to promise to do something.

• [ + (that) ] You might find it difficult to believe, but I swear (that) the guy just came up to me and gave me the money.

• A few of us knew what was going to happen, but we were sworn to secrecy (= we were made to promise to keep it a secret).
• I think his birthday is on the 5th, but I wouldn't/couldn't swear to it (= I am not completely certain about it).

Definition: To swing something means to move it back and forth or from side to side.
Example: He can swing a golf club very powerfully.

Definition: To combine is to join together to make a single thing or group.
Example: Mina combined peanut butter and jelly to make a sandwich.

Definition: When something is contemporary, it is related to the present time.
Example: contemporary scientists have learned quite a bit about DNA.
Cambridge Examples:

Definition: When it is humid, there is a lot of water in the air.
Example: It is very humid inside of a sauna.
Cambridge Examples:

Definition: When something is rapid, it moves or changes very quickly.
Example: His mother was surprised by her son's rapid growth.

Definition: A rate is the speed at which something happens.
Example: Grass tends to grow at a very slow rate.
Cambridge Examples:
• Although she's recovering from her illness, her rate of progress is quite slow.

Definition: When something is toxic, it is poisonous. Those things are very dangerous.

Definition: To vary means to be different from another thing in size or amount.
Example: The heights of the people in my class vary by a large amount.
Cambridge Examples:
• Salary scales vary between states/from state to state/according to state/with each state.
• The samples varied in quality but were generally acceptable.
• We have tried several different approaches, with varying degrees of success.

Definition: Your character is your personality.
Example: My sister's character is fun and very outgoing.
Cambridge Examples:
• Politeness is traditionally part of the British character.
• It would be very out of character (= not typical) of her to lie.
• One of the joys of being a parent is watching the child's character develop.
• The idea was to modernize various aspects of the house without changing its essential character.
• It's not in his character to be (= he is not usually) jealous.

Definition: When something is sour, it has a sharp, and sometimes unpleasant, taste.
Example: I don't like lemons because I think they are too sour.
Cambridge Examples: • These plums are a bit sour.

Definition: string is a thin piece of fabric or rope.
Example: I found a large ball of string.
Cambridge Examples:
• a package tied with string
• a ball/piece of string
• When you pull the strings, the puppet's arms and legs move.

Definition: If someone is conscious of something, then they are aware of it.
Example: The new student was conscious of the other students staring at her.
Cambridge Examples:
• My tooth doesn't exactly hurt, but I'm conscious of it (= I can feel it) all the time.
• [ + -ing verb ] I think she's very conscious of being the only person in the office who didn't have a university education.
• [ + that ] He gradually became conscious (of the fact) that everyone else was wearing a suit.

Definition: To disagree with someone means to have a different opinion from them.
Example: The lawyer disagreed about the best way to settle the case.
Cambridge Examples:
• I'm afraid I have to disagree with you (on that issue).
• [ + that ] Few people would disagree that something should be done to reduce crime in the area.
• I profoundly/strongly disagree with (= do not accept) the decision that has been made.

Definition: A hint is information that suggests something will happen or is true.
Example: I quietly passed on a hint to my sister about the test.
Cambridge Examples:
• Could you give us a hint about how to do this exercise, please?
• This recipe book is full of handy (= useful) hints.

Definition: An idiot is a person who is not smart or who has done something silly.
Example: Because he got lost in the forest, the man felt like an idiot.
Cambridge Examples:
• Some idiot left the tap running in the bathroom and there's water everywhere.
• [ as form of address ] You stupid idiot - that's a month's work you've lost!

Definition: An option is a choice between two or more things.
Example: The children were given the option of three houses to pick from.
Cambridge Examples:
• The best option would be to cancel the trip altogether.
• There are various options open to someone who is willing to work hard.
• They didn't leave him much option - either he paid or they'd beat him up.

Definition: To switch means to change something to something else.
Example: Mom switched the TV station from the news to her favorite show.
Cambridge Examples:
• She started studying English, but switched to History in her second year.
• In 1971, Britain switched over (= changed completely) to a decimal currency.
• After the bank robbery, the gang switched cars (= left one car and got into another).

Definition: If something or someone is thorough, then they are complete in every way.
Example: Tina did a thorough job of cleaning the stains out of the carpet.
Cambridge Examples:
• a thorough revision of the manuscript
• They did a thorough search of the area but found nothing.

Definition: If something is damp, it is somewhat wet.
Example: My hair is still damp from my shower.
Cambridge Examples:
• The grass is still damp.
• This shirt still feels a bit damp.
• It was a damp, misty morning.

Definition: To disapprove of something is to think that it is wrong.
Example: Alex disapproved of his son's behavior.
Cambridge Examples:
• The survey showed that 32 percent of respondents approve, 54 percent disapprove, and the rest are undecided.
• I strongly disapprove of underage drinking.

Definition: When someone is fond of something, they like it.
Example: I am very fond of chocolate cake.
Cambridge Examples:
• She was very fond of horses.
• "I'm very fond of you, you know," he said.
• My brother is fond of pointing out my mistakes.

Definition: When something or someone is immoral, they are evil or do bad things.
Example: Stealing money from one's mother is an immoral act.
Cambridge Examples:
• an immoral act
• immoral behaviour
• It's an immoral tax, because the poor will pay relatively more.

Definition: If something is trivial, it is not important or meaningful.
Example: Television is trivial, but learning to read is very important.
Cambridge Examples:
• I don't know why he gets so upset about something so trivial.
• Sexual harassment in the workplace is not a trivial matter.

Definition: If something is typical, it is normal for a certain type of thing.
Example: Barking is typical behavior for dogs.
Cambridge Examples:
• I must look like the typical tourist with my shorts and my camera.
• This kind of hot and spicy food is very typical of the food in the south of the country.
• Typical symptoms would include severe headaches, vomiting and dizziness.

Definition: To edit means to correct a piece of writing so that it is suitable to be published.
Example: She asked her brother to edit her paper before she submitted it to her teacher.
Cambridge Examples:
• Janet edited books for a variety of publishers.
• The movie's 129 minutes were edited down from 150 hours of footage.

Definition: An essay is a short piece of writing on a certain subject.
Example: She had to write a two-page essay for her English class.
Cambridge Examples:
• For homework I want you to write an essay on endangered species.
• Mr Jones thought my history essay was terrific.

Definition: To faint means to go unconscious and fall down.
Example: Carol fainted because she hadn't eaten in over a day.
Cambridge Examples:
• He faints at the sight of blood.
• I nearly fainted in the heat.
• She took one look at the hypodermic needle and fainted (dead) away (= became unconscious immediately).

Definition: If something is global, it happens all around the world.
Example: Pollution is a global problem.
Cambridge Examples: • a global catastrophe/problem

Definition: To highlight something means to mark it with a color so that it is easy to see.
Example: I read my vocabulary list and highlighted the most difficult words.
Cambridge Examples:
• The report highlights the need for improved safety.
• The spelling mistakes in the text had been highlighted in green.

Definition: A lecture is a long, educational speech.
Example: His lecture on world hunger was very informative.
Cambridge Examples:
• We went to a lecture on Italian art.
• Who's giving the lecture this afternoon?

Definition: To operate means to work or function.
Example: I'm sorry, but the trains are not operateing today.
Cambridge Examples:
• How do you operate the remote control unit?
• Does the company operate a pension scheme?
• For several years she operated a dating agency from her basement.
• Changes are being introduced to make the department operate more efficiently.
• Specially equipped troops are operating in the hills.
• We have representatives operating in most countries.
• Exchange rates are currently operating to the advantage of exporters.

Definition: If something is private, it is only used by one person or group.
Example: Don't look at my diary! It's private!
Cambridge Examples:
• She has a small office that is used for private discussions.
• I caught him looking through my private papers.
• The sign on the gate said "Private Property - No Trespassing!"

Definition: When something is recent, it happened a short time ago.
Example: I did not know what caused his recent behavior.
Cambridge Examples:
• Is that a recent photo?
• Have you been following recent political events?
• In recent times/years/months, etc. there has been an increase in the amount of violence on television.

Definition: When something is weird, it is very strange.
Example: My best friend's dad is a bit weird.
Cambridge Examples:
• He was sitting alone by a window with a weird contraption on the table in front of him.
• Her boyfriend's a bit weird but she's nice.
• That's weird - I thought I left my keys on the table but they're not there.
• There is nothing to rival the weird and wonderful things that come out on the Rio streets at carnival time.

Definition: If something is absolute, it is total or complete.
Example: My presentation was an absolute disaster! It was terrible!
Cambridge Examples:
• a man of absolute integrity/discretion
• I have absolute faith in her judgment.
• There was no absolute proof of fraud.

Definition: folk are common or average people.
Example: I've invited all the folks from our street to a gathering at my place.
Cambridge Examples:
• old folk
• Ordinary folk can't afford cars like that.

Definition: To melt means to turn from a solid to a liquid.
Example: The snowman that we made yesterday melted in the sun.
Cambridge Examples:
• The snow usually melts by mid March.
• Melt the chocolate slowly so that it doesn't burn.
• The meat's beautifully cooked - it melts in your mouth (= is so pleasantly soft that you do not need to chew it).

Definition: pleasure is a feeling of happiness.
Example: The student smiled with pleasure when she received the prize.
Cambridge Examples:
• His visits gave his grandparents such pleasure.
• Why do so many boys take pleasure in torturing insects and small animals?
• [ + to infinitive ] It was such a pleasure to meet you.
• He wrote an article on the pleasures and pains of camping.
• Coffee is one of my few pleasures.

Definition: A pudding is a sweet dessert.
Example: Would you like some chocolate pudding and coffee for dessert?
Cambridge Examples:
• a sticky toffee/treacle pudding
• Is there any more rice pudding?

Definition: A recipe is a set of instructions to make food.
Example: The apple cake that you made is really tasty. Can I have the recipe, please?
Cambridge Examples:
• For real South Asian food, just follow these recipes.
• Do you know a good recipe for wholemeal bread?

Definition: A role is the normal purpose or function of a person or thing.
Example: My role at work is to check the quality of the products.
Cambridge Examples:
• What is his role in this project?
• Schools play an important role in society.
• Six people have been put on trial for their role (= involvement) in the anti-government demonstrations.

Definition: To shrink means to get smaller.
Example: If you stick to a healthy diet, your stomach will shrink!
Cambridge Examples:
• Your sweater will shrink if you wash it at too high a temperature.
• The company's profits have shrunk from $5.5 million to $1.25 million.
• The productivity improvements have shrunk our costs by 25 percent.

Definition: An account with a bank is an arrangement to keep one's money there.
Example: After I paid for the new car, my bank account was nearly empty.
Cambridge Examples:
• I've opened an account with a building society.
• I paid the money into my account this morning.
• UK She paid the cheque into her account.
• US She deposited the check in her account.
• I need to draw some money out of my account.

Definition: An architect is a person who designs buildings.
Example: The plans for building the new home were drawn by a famous architect.
Cambridge Examples:
• After years of study, Tim is now a fully-fledged architect.
• The architect has quoted £10,000 to build an extension.
• She is a highly recommended architect.
• He is probably the best known living architect.
• The architect showed us the house plans that she had drawn up.
• They're the firm of architects who won the contract to design the National Museum extension.
• The architects have made imaginative use of glass and transparent plastic.

Definition: A crime is something bad that a person does that can be punished by law.
Example: Police quickly arrived at the scene of the crime.
Cambridge Examples:
• He has admitted committing several crimes, including fraud.
• The defendant is accused of/charged with a range of crimes, from theft to murder.
• He should not be allowed to question the victims of his alleged crimes.
• A knife was found at the scene of the crime/the crime scene.

Definition: If something is legal, it is related to the law or allowed by the law.
Example: It was not legal for him to drive untill he was eighteen years old.
Cambridge Examples:
• legal advice
• a legal obligation/requirement
• legal status
• your legal rights
• legal action/proceedings
• my legal representatives (= my lawyers)

Definition: If something is memorable, then it is remembered for a special reason.
Example: The party was memorable; people were still talking about it years later.
Cambridge Examples:
• a memorable performance
• a memorable tune
• I haven't seen them since that memorable evening when the boat capsized.

Definition: resources are a person or country's money and materials that they can use.
Example: The poor man didn't have the resources to feed himself.
Cambridge Examples:
• The country's greatest resource is the dedication of its workers.
• Britain's mineral resources include coal and gas deposits.

Definition: A sentence is punishment given to someone who didn't follow the law.
Example: The sentence for stealing a car is much worse than for stealing candy.
Cambridge Examples:
• He got a heavy/light sentence (= he was severely/not severely punished).
• The offence carries a jail/prison/life/five-year sentence.
• He was given a non-custodial/suspended sentence.

Definition: A witness is someone who sees or hears a crime or accident happen.
Example: The woman was the only witness of the horrible crime.
Cambridge Examples:
• Police are appealing for witnesses to the accident to come forward.
• According to (eye) witnesses, the robbery was carried out by two teenage boys.

Definition: access is the right to enter or use something.
Example: The manager was the only person with access to the password.
Cambridge Examples:
• The only access to the village is by boat.
• The main access to (= entrance to) the building is at the side.
• The children's father was refused access to them at any time (= refused official permission to see them).

Definition: conduct is the way that someone acts.
Example: She was punished for her bad conduct.
Cambridge Examples:
• We are conducting a survey to find out what our customers think of their local bus service.
• The experiments were conducted by scientists in New York.
• How you choose to conduct your private life is your own business!

Definition: When an event or action is constant, it happens a lot or all the time.
Example: The television at home is in constant use.
Cambridge Examples:
• He's in constant trouble with the police.
• machines that are in constant use

Definition: A device is an object or a machine.
Example: A thermometer is a device that tells temperature.
Cambridge Examples:
• a contraceptive/electronic device
• Rescuers used a special device for finding people trapped in collapsed buildings.

Definition: To grip something is to hold it very tightly.
Example: I was scared, so I gripped my older sister's hand.
Cambridge Examples:
• The baby gripped my finger with her tiny hand.
• Old tyres won't grip (= stay on the surface of the road) in the rain very well.

Definition: To influence someone or something is to have an effect over them.
Example: My friend influenced my decision to attend Terrance University.
Cambridge Examples:
• She's very good at making friends and influencing people.
• [ + obj + to infinitive ] What influenced you to choose a career in nursing?

Definition: A law is a rule made by the legislative body.
Example: The students learned about different laws during social studies class.
Cambridge Examples:
• There are laws against drinking in the street.
• The laws governing the possession of firearms are being reviewed.
• They led the fight to impose laws on smoking.
• [ + -ing verb or + to infinitive ] Many doctors backed plans for a law banning/to ban all tobacco advertising.

Definition: To replace something is to put it in the place of something else.
Example: I replaced the tire on my car because it was flat.
Cambridge Examples:
• The factory replaced most of its workers with robots.
• Tourism has replaced agriculture as the nation's main industry.

Definition: To tend to do something is to be likely to do it or to do it often.
Example: My mom tends to buy me the perfect gift each Christmas.
Cambridge Examples: • [ + to infinitive ] We tend to get cold winters and warm, dry summers in this part of the country.

Definition: When something is valid, it is correct or based on good reasoning.
Example: The expert's opinion on the subject was more valid than others.
Cambridge Examples:
• a valid argument/criticism/reason
• My way of thinking might be different from yours, but it's equally valid.

Definition: A version is an account of something that differs slightly from the original.
Example: She read the students British version of the Chinese fairy tale.
Cambridge Examples:
• The official version of events is that the police were attacked and were just trying to defend themselves.
• You can make a reduced fat version of the cheesecake by using cottage cheese instead of cream cheese.
• An English-language version of the book is planned for next year.
• The TV series is a watered-down version of the movie, especially designed for family viewing.

Definition: convenience is a state of being able to do something with little effort.
Example: The Internet allows consumers to shop at their own convenience.
Cambridge Examples:
• I like the convenience of living close to work.
• Just for convenience, I'm going to live at my mother's place until my new apartment is ready.

Definition: To deprive someone of something means to not let them have it.
Example: Because the child was bad, she was deprived of her dessert after dinner.
Cambridge Examples:
• He claimed that he had been deprived of his freedom/rights.
• You can't function properly when you're deprived of sleep.

Definition: A headquarters is a building where the bosses of a company work.
Example: He drove the long route to headquarters because it was a nice day.
Cambridge Examples:
• The company's headquarters is/are in Amsterdam.
• The rebel headquarters took a direct hit from a bomb during the attack.
• The company's national headquarters is in Rome.
• A surgical strike was carried out on the enemy's military headquarters.
• The new company headquarters will be built on a 132-acre tract in Irving.
• The divisional managers have been called to a meeting at the company headquarters.

Definition: rubbish is trash or waste.
Example: The floor around the garbage can was covered with all kinds of rubbish.
Cambridge Examples:
• I forgot to put the rubbish out this morning.
• Put the empty box in the rubbish bin.
• Take the old furniture to the rubbish dump.

Definition: To assess something means to judge the structure, purpose, or quality of it.
Example: She assessed the condition of the toy car before buying it.
Cambridge Examples:
• The insurers will need to assess the flood damage.
• They assessed the cost of the flood damage at £2,500.
• Exams are not the only means of assessing a student's ability.
• It's too early to assess the long-term consequences of the two countries' union.
• [ + question word ] We need to assess whether the project is worth doing.

Definition: To extract something means to remove it, especially with difficulty.
Example: The dentist extracted the woman’s damaged tooth and put in a fake one.
Cambridge Examples:
• They used to extract iron ore from this site.
• The oil which is extracted from olives is used for cooking.
• The tooth was eventually extracted.

Definition: latter describes something last in a series or the second choice of two things.
Example: In the latter minutes of the game, the visitors scored the winning goal.
Cambridge Examples:
• Building of the new library should begin in the latter part of next year.
• In the latter stages of the fight he began to tire.

Definition: If someone is precise, then they are exact and careful about their work.
Example: The builder was very precise about where he placed the nails.
Cambridge Examples:
• The bunker's precise location is a closely guarded secret.
• He caught me at the precise moment that I fainted.
• There was a good turnout for the meeting - twelve of us to be precise.

Definition: publicity is public attention given to someone or something by the media.
Example: She received a lot of publicity after her performance in the film.
Cambridge Examples:
• He attracted a lot of adverse/bad publicity with his speech about unmarried mothers.
• Her first novel was published last year in a blaze of (= with a lot of) publicity.
• We have planned an exciting publicity campaign with our advertisers.
• The publicity generated by the court case has given a welcome boost to our sales.
• The normally publicity-shy director will be making several public appearances for the launch of the movie.
• The enormous publicity surrounding the case will make it very difficult to hold a fair trial.
• The pop group's arrival by hot-air balloon was just a publicity stunt (= an unusual way of attracting the public's attention).

Definition: A remedy is a cure for a disease, argument, or problem.
Example: A good remedy for a headache is an aspirin and a glass of water.
Cambridge Examples:
• an effective herbal remedy for headaches
• The best remedy for grief is hard work.

Definition: To implement something means to ensure that what has been planned is done.
Example: The school decided to implement a new teaching strategy.
Cambridge Examples: • The changes to the national health system will be implemented next year.

Definition: When something is peculiar, it is strange, sometimes in a bad way.
Example: That peculiar smell coming from the kitchen reminds me of rotten eggs.
Cambridge Examples:
• She has the most peculiar ideas.
• What a peculiar smell!
• It's peculiar that they didn't tell us they were going away.
• UK The video on road accidents made me feel rather peculiar (= ill).

Definition: To tolerate something means to be able to accept it even when it is unpleasant.
Example: When you are in a hurry, it can be hard to tolerate traffic signals.
Cambridge Examples:
• I will not tolerate that kind of behaviour in my class.
• [ + -ing verb ] I won't tolerate lying.

Definition: When something is bizarre, it is very strange.
Example: My bizarre dreams make no sense to me when I am awake.
Cambridge Examples:
• a bizarre situation
• bizarre behaviour

Definition: A companion is a person that someone spends a lot of time with.
Example: I always walk to school with my companion Frank.
Cambridge Examples:
• The dog has been her constant companion these past ten years.
• a travelling companion

Definition: If something is dense, it has a lot of things close together.
Example: I easily became lost in the dense forest.
Cambridge Examples:
• dense fog
• a dense forest
• The body was found hidden in dense undergrowth.

Definition: To dominate someone or something is to control them.
Example: The loud man dominated the conversation.
Cambridge Examples:
• He refuses to let others speak and dominates every meeting.
• They work as a group - no one person is allowed to dominate.

Definition: To peel fruits and vegetables is to remove their skin.
Example: We peeled the apple before eating it.
Cambridge Examples: • Peel, core, and chop the apples.

Definition: A prescription is permission from a doctor to get medicine.
Example: The doctor gave me a prescription for my medication.
Cambridge Examples:
• a doctor's prescription
• a prescription for sedatives
• The doctor should give you a repeat prescription (= another piece of paper allowing more of the same medicine to be given, often without the person seeing the doctor again).
• These drugs are only available on prescription (= with a prescription from a doctor).
• Prescription charges (= the standard amount of money you pay for any medicine prescribed by a doctor) are rising in June.

Definition: If something is medieval, it comes from the period between 650 and 1500 CE.
Example: We visited a castle that was built during medieval times.
Cambridge Examples:
• a medieval building/painting/town
• a medieval manuscript

Definition: If something is spectacular, it looks or sounds very impressive.
Example: There was a spectacular fireworks display in the park at New Year.
Cambridge Examples: • We've had spectacular success with the product.

Definition: An accountant is a person whose job is to keep financial accounts.
Example: The accountant helped me keep track of my money.
Cambridge Examples: • a firm of accountants

Definition: To finance someone or something means to provide money for them.
Example: The government financed the scientist’s experiments with new weapons.
Cambridge Examples: • The city council has refused to finance the project.

Definition: A biography is an account of someone’s life that is written by someone else.
Example: We read a biography about Charles Darwin in science class.
Cambridge Examples: • He wrote a biography of Winston Churchill.

Definition: To boost something means to increase or improve it.
Example: Lowering prices boosts customers’ interest in shopping.
Cambridge Examples:
• The theatre managed to boost its audiences by cutting ticket prices.
• Share prices were boosted by reports of the president's recovery.
• I tried to boost his ego (= make him feel more confident) by praising his cooking.

Definition: To clap means to hit one’s hands together to express pleasure or get attention.
Example: After the speech, everyone in the crowd clapped their hands for the speaker.
Cambridge Examples:
• "When I clap my hands, you stand still," said the teacher.
• The band played a familiar tune which had everyone clapping along.
• The audience clapped in time to the music.

Definition: When something is gorgeous, it is very pleasing and attractive.
Example: The girl picked out a gorgeous dress to wear to the dance.
Cambridge Examples:
• What a gorgeous room/dress/colour!
• The bride looked gorgeous.
• The weather was so gorgeous.

Definition: When a thing is talked about overall, the whole thing is considered.
Example: overall, the party was a huge success.
Cambridge Examples:
• The overall situation is good, despite a few minor problems.
• Overall, it has been a good year.
• The overall winner, after ten games, will receive $250,000.

Definition: feedback is comments to a person about how they are doing something.
Example: I asked my boss for feedback on my work.
Cambridge Examples:
• Have you had any feedback from customers about the new soap?
• positive/negative feedback

Definition: A monument is a structure that is built to remind people of a person or event.
Example: A large monument was built to honor the brave soldiers.
Cambridge Examples: • In the square in front of the hotel stands a monument to all the people killed in the war.

Definition: To supervise something means to make sure that it is done correctly.
Example: Allen supervised the construction workers to ensure everyone’s safety.
Cambridge Examples:
• The UN is supervising the distribution of aid by local agencies in the disaster area.
• The children play while two teachers supervise (= make certain that they behave correctly and are safe).

Definition: To entitle someone means to give them the rights to have or do something.
Example: His golden ticket entitled him to sit in the front row at the concert.
Cambridge Examples:
• Being unemployed entitles you to free medical treatment.
• [ + to infinitive ] The employer is entitled to ask for references.

Definition: When something is external, it is connected to an outer part.
Example: It is warm inside my house, but the external temperature is freezing.
Cambridge Examples:
• the external walls of the house
• Female kangaroos carry their young in pouches that are external to their bodies.
• This cream is for external use only (= it must not be put inside the body).
• In later years, his paintings began to show a number of external influences (= influences coming from other people).
• Most news magazines have a section devoted to external affairs (= foreign news).
• You shouldn't judge people by their external appearances (= what they appear to be like).

Definition: A facility is a building that exists for a particular purpose.
Example: There are many educational facilities in big cities.
Cambridge Examples:
• a nuclear research facility
• a military facility
• a new sports facility

Definition: A pedestrian is a person who is walking on a street.
Example: Cars should be careful when pedestrians are walking around.
Cambridge Examples:
• A few pedestrians sheltered from the rain in doorways.
• The death rate for pedestrians hit by cars is unacceptably high.

Definition: A spectator is someone who watches something, especially a sports event.
Example: There were thousands of spectators at the big game.
Cambridge Examples: • They won 4–0 in front of over 40,000 cheering spectators.

Definition: An aspect is one part or feature of something.
Example: I thought about the different aspects of owning two dogs.
Cambridge Examples:
• Which aspects of the job do you most enjoy?
• His illness affects almost every aspect of his life.
• That's the most worrying aspect of the situation.
• Lighting is a vitally important aspect of filmmaking.
• Have you thought about the problem from every aspect?

Definition: To specify is to describe something clearly.
Example: The poster didn’t specify where the concert was taking place.
Cambridge Examples:
• He said we should meet but didn't specify a time.
• The peace treaty clearly specifies the terms for the withdrawal of troops.
• [ + question word ] The newspaper report did not specify how the men were killed.
• [ + (that) ] My contract specifies (that) I must give a month's notice if I leave my job.
• The loan must be repaid within a specified period/by a specified date.

Definition: When something is adequate, it is good enough for something else.
Example: Without adequate notice of the road block, they will have to turn around.
Cambridge Examples:
• Have we got adequate food for 20 guests?
• I didn't have adequate time to prepare.
• It's not a big salary but it's adequate for our needs.
• The council's provision for the elderly is barely adequate (= is not enough).
• [ + to infinitive ] Will future oil supplies be adequate to meet world needs?

Definition: cardboard is a material made out of stiff paper. It is often used to make boxes.
Example: We packed our things into cardboard boxes and moved to our new home.
Cambridge Examples: • a cardboard box

Definition: A dilemma is a difficult situation in which a choice has to be made.
Example: Choosing either the tastier or healthier drink proved to be quite a dilemma.
Cambridge Examples:
• The president is clearly in a dilemma about/over how to tackle the crisis.
• She faces the dilemma of disobeying her father or losing the man she loves.
• a moral/ethical dilemma

Definition: To import means to bring in a product from another country.
Example: Foods that have been imported are usually more expensive.
Cambridge Examples: • We import a large number of cars from Japan.

Definition: An update is an act of making something more modern.
Example: I’m doing an update on my personal phone directory.
Cambridge Examples: • an updated version of the software

Definition: An addict is a person who cannot stop doing or having something.
Example: She was a coffee addict. She had more than three cups each day.
Cambridge Examples:
• a drug/heroin addict
• a gambling addict
• humorous I'm a chocolate/shopping addict.

Definition: A budget is the amount of money available to spend on something.
Example: His budget for food was very tight.
Cambridge Examples: • an annual budget of £40 million

Definition: To correspond is to match or to be similar to something.
Example: The boy’s story didn’t correspond with his mother’s version.
Cambridge Examples:
• The money I've saved corresponds roughly to the amount I need for my plane ticket.
• The American FBI corresponds to the British MI5.
• His story of what happened that night didn't correspond with the witness's version.

Definition: An estate is a large area of land owned by a family or organization.
Example: He lived on his father’s estate in the country.
Cambridge Examples: • It's a typical country estate with a large house for the owner, farm buildings, and estate workers' houses.

Definition: To knit is to make fabric by connecting strings together.
Example: My grandmother knitted me a sweater.
Cambridge Examples:
• She's forever knitting.
• She's busy knitting baby clothes.
• [ + two objects ] My granny knitted me some gloves/knitted some gloves for me.

Definition: A parachute is a device that helps people and things fall to the ground safely.
Example: They used parachutes dropped from airplanes to send supplies to the civilians.
Cambridge Examples:
• a parachute harness
• Airborne troops were dropped by parachute behind enemy lines.
• For whatever reason his parachute failed to open.
• She's agreed to do a parachute jump for charity.
• There was a large tear in his parachute.

Definition: discipline is training that helps people follow the rules.
Example: One of the teacher’s jobs is to teach her students discipline.
Cambridge Examples:
• parental/military/school discipline
• There should be tougher discipline in schools.
• I don't have enough (self) discipline to save money.

Definition: A fellow is someone who shares a job or quality with someone else.
Example: All of my fellow patients at the hospital have also complained about the food.
Cambridge Examples:
• She introduced me to some of her fellow students.
• Our fellow travellers were mostly Spanish-speaking tourists.

Definition: gossip is information that might be untrue but is still discussed anyway.
Example: The friends exchanged gossip about the people they knew in school.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her letter was full of gossip.
• I don't like all this idle gossip.
• I've got some juicy gossip for you.
• Have you heard the (latest) gossip?
• UK Jane and Lyn sat in the kitchen having a good gossip about their friends.

Definition: To graduate from a school means to complete and pass all courses of study there.
Example: At the end of the spring, my friends and I will graduate from high school.
Cambridge Examples:
• Lorna graduated from Freiburg University.
• Tom has just graduated with first-class honours in psychology.

Definition: A referee is a person who makes sure that the rules are followed in sports.
Example: The soccer player didn’t agree with the referee.
Cambridge Examples: • We only lost the game because the referee was biased.

Definition: To stab means to cut someone or something with a sharp object like a knife.
Example: He stabbed the fork into the potato and passed it to his daughter.
Cambridge Examples:
• She was stabbed several times in the chest.
• He was jailed for 15 years for stabbing his wife to death.

Definition: A theme is the main subject of a book, movie, or painting.
Example: The students discussed the book’s theme in class.
Cambridge Examples: • The theme of loss runs through most of his novels.

Definition: If someone is aggressive, then they constantly want to fight.
Example: Nobody liked to play games with him because he was always too aggressive.
Cambridge Examples:
• The stereotype is that men tend to be more aggressive than women.
• If I criticize him, he gets aggressive and starts shouting.

Definition: To distract someone means to stop them from concentrating on something.
Example: The phone call distracted him so much that he forgot all about his homework.
Cambridge Examples:
• Don't distract her (from her studies).
• He tried to distract attention from his own illegal activities.

Definition: context is the situations that form the background of an event.
Example: They studied the context of the battle before giving their presentation.
Cambridge Examples:
• It is important to see all the fighting and bloodshed in his plays in historical context.
• This small battle is very important in the context of Scottish history.

Definition: If something is frequent, then it happens or is done often.
Example: While Dad was sick, the doctor made frequent visits to his house.
Cambridge Examples:
• a frequent visitor to the US
• A frequent criticism of the proposal has been its high cost.
• The most frequent cause of death is heart disease.
• The attacks were increasingly frequent and serious.

Definition: When something is genuine, it is true or real.
Example: After the painting was determined to be genuine, it sold for a million dollars.
Cambridge Examples:
• genuine leather
• If it is a genuine Michelangelo drawing, it will sell for millions.

Definition: A database is a collection of data that is stored in a computer.
Example: The company has a database of all the names and accounts of their customers.
Cambridge Examples: • We're linked to the online database at our head office.

Definition: input is information that is put into a computer.
Example: Type the input into the computer program.
Cambridge Examples:
• I didn't have much input into the project (= the help I gave was small).
• The power input will come largely from hydroelectricity.

Definition: A phase is a stage in a process or the gradual development of something.
Example: The first phase in the recycling project involves finding volunteers to help out.
Cambridge Examples:
• The project is only in its initial phase as yet, but it's looking quite promising.
• We're entering a new phase in international relations.

Definition: To dash means to run or move quickly.
Example: Helen dashed up the stairs, so she wouldn’t be late for her appointment.
Cambridge Examples:
• The dog ran off, and she dashed after him.
• UK I've been dashing around all day.
• UK I must dash - I've got to be home by seven.

Definition: If you are furious, you are extremely angry.
Example: My father was furious when he read my bad school report.
Cambridge Examples:
• I was late and he was furious with me.
• He's furious about/at the way he's been treated.
• We had a furious debate about the death penalty.

Definition: An acid is a chemical that can burn or dissolve other substances.
Example: In chemistry class, we mixed two acids together and watched the reaction.
Cambridge Examples:
• acetic/hydrochloric/lactic acid
• Vinegar is an acid.

Definition: To manufacture something means to make it in a factory.
Example: My father’s company manufactures steel building materials.
Cambridge Examples: • She insisted that every scandalous detail of the story had been manufactured.

Definition: When something is straightforward, it is good because it is easy to understand.
Example: The teacher’s grading system was straightforward and fair.
Cambridge Examples: • Just follow the signs to Bradford - it's very straightforward.

Definition: An atom is the smallest unit of a substance.
Example: A molecule consists of a combination of two or more atoms.
Cambridge Examples:
• A molecule of carbon dioxide (CO2) has one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms.
• figurative He hasn't an atom of sense (= he has no sense), that boy.

Definition: despair is the complete loss of hope.
Example: After the other company won the account, our salespeople were filled with despair.
Cambridge Examples:
• a mood/sense of despair
• They're in (the depths of) despair over/about the money they've lost.
• To her teacher's despair, Nicole never does the work that she's told to do.
• Their fourth year without rain drove many farmers to despair.

Definition: To employ someone means to give work to them.
Example: The bookstore employed two full-time clerks.
Cambridge Examples:
• How many people does your company employ?
• Can't we employ someone as an assistant to help with all this paperwork?
• [ + to infinitive ] We've employed a market researcher to find out what people really want from a cable TV system.
• More people are now employed in service industries than in manufacturing.

Definition: An extension is a part added to something to give it more time or space.
Example: My parents decided to add an extension to our house for the new baby.
Cambridge Examples:
• Martin Luther King, Jr, campaigned for the extension of civil rights to (= for them to include) black people.
• The extension (= increasing) of police powers in the province has been heavily criticized.
• His report contained serious criticisms of the finance director, and, by extension (= therefore), of the entire board of management.
• The article is an extension of (= takes further) the ideas Professor Fox developed in an earlier book.
• I've applied for an extension to my visa (= asked for it to last longer).
• They are hoping to get an extension of their loan (= to be given a longer period of time in which to pay it back).

Definition: If something is forthcoming, then it is about to happen in the future.
Example: Some economists predicted that the forthcoming world economy would be severe.
Cambridge Examples: • We have just received the information about the forthcoming conference.

Definition: A landlord is a man who rents property to a person.
Example: The landlord collected everyone’s rent money on the first day of every month.
Cambridge Examples:
• The landlord had promised to redecorate the bedrooms before we moved in.
• Housing associations are the biggest landlords in this area.

Definition: To mend something means to fix it when it is broken or damaged.
Example: Mother mended the rip in my pants with a piece of cloth.
Cambridge Examples:
• Could you mend this hole in my shirt?
• UK I've left my watch at the jeweller's to be mended.
• UK The plumber came to mend the burst pipe.
• The country's president is seeking to mend relations with the United States.

Definition: If someone is arrogant, they think that they are more important than others.
Example: He is very arrogant. Even though he’s not the boss, he tells everyone what to do.
Cambridge Examples:
• I found him arrogant and rude.
• She has an authoritative manner that at times is almost arrogant.
• I watched the interview and thought he seemed quite arrogant.
• He manages to exude confidence without being arrogant.
• Like a lot of hospital consultants, he terrifies his patients with his arrogant manner.
• If I say I'm a leading economic expert, won't that sound rather arrogant?

Definition: If something is nasty, then it is not nice or pleasant.
Example: The rotten apple left a nasty taste inside her mouth.
Cambridge Examples:
• a nasty shock/surprise
• There's a nasty smell in here.
• He had a nasty cut above the eye.
• She has a nasty habit of picking on people in meetings.

Definition: If something is sticky, then it is covered with a substance that things stick to.
Example: Place the sticky part of the tape against the paper, so it will cling to the wall.
Cambridge Examples:
• a sticky mess
• sticky fingers
• The floor's still sticky where I spilled the juice.
• The children's faces were sticky with chocolate.

Definition: A trail is a path through a wild area.
Example: A narrow trail cut through the field and over the hills.
Cambridge Examples:
• a forest/mountain trail
• a walking/snowshoeing/cross-country skiing trail

Definition: If something is done on one’s behalf, it is done for that person by another.
Example: The original speaker was sick, so his son gave the speech on his behalf.
Cambridge Examples:
• On behalf of the entire company, I would like to thank you for all your work.
• Unfortunately, George cannot be with us today so I am pleased to accept this award on his behalf.
• She wasn't able to be present, so I signed the letter in her behalf.

Definition: A loaf of bread is bread shaped and baked in one piece.
Example: Could you please buy a loaf of bread for sandwiches?
Cambridge Examples: • two loaves of white bread

Definition: If something is previous, then it happened earlier in time or order.
Example: He turned back to the previous page to read the paragraph again.
Cambridge Examples:
• The previous owner of the house had built an extension on the back.
• Training is provided, so no previous experience is required for the job.
• He has two daughters from a previous marriage.

Definition: To provide something means to supply it.
Example: Each student was provided with a test and three sharp pencils.
Cambridge Examples:
• This booklet provides useful information about local services.
• All meals are provided at no additional cost.
• The author provides no documentary references to support her assertions.
• We have concerns about whether the government will be able to provide viable social services for poorer families/provide poorer families with viable social services.
• Putting more police on patrol doesn't provide a real solution to the problem of increasing violence.

Definition: When something is relevant, it is important to a certain person or situation.
Example: The thirty-year-old book about politics is still relevant to our society today.
Cambridge Examples:
• Education should be relevant to the child's needs.
• For further information, please refer to the relevant leaflet.
• The point is highly relevant to this discussion.
• I'm sorry but your personal wishes are not relevant (= important) in this case.

Definition: If something is supernatural, it is not real or explainable by natural law.
Example: The dragon had supernatural powers such as flying and breathing fire.
Cambridge Examples:
• Ghosts and evil spirits are supernatural.
• She is said to have supernatural powers and to be able to communicate with the dead.

Definition: To adapt means to change in order to deal with a new situation or addition.
Example: When he went to the new town, he had to adapt to all the weather changes.
Cambridge Examples:
• Many software companies have adapted popular programs to the new operating system.
• The recipe here is a pork roast adapted from Caroline O'Neill's book "Louisiana Kitchen".
• [ + to infinitive ] We had to adapt our plans to fit Jack's timetable.
• The play had been adapted for (= changed to make it suitable for) children.
• Davies is busy adapting Brinkworth's latest novel for television.

Definition: biological describes the process of life and living things.
Example: In science, we learned about the biological process of bacterial growth.
Cambridge Examples:
• the biological sciences
• Eating is a biological necessity!

Definition: When people are dynamic, they are lively and have creative ideas.
Example: The new, dynamic employee came up with a good way to juggle his work load.
Cambridge Examples:
• She's young and dynamic and will be a great addition to the team.
• We need a dynamic expansion of trade with other countries.

Definition: A fantasy is a pleasant situation that people think about but is unlikely to happen.
Example: Becoming an astronaut is a fantasy shared by many children.
Cambridge Examples:
• Steve's favourite fantasy was to own a big house and a flashy car.
• sexual fantasies
• She retreated into a fantasy world, where she could be anything she wanted.

Definition: When something is internal, it exists or happens inside a person, object, or place.
Example: We removed the outer case to reveal the computer’s internal wires.
Cambridge Examples: • He sustained injuries to his arms, legs, and several internal organs.

Definition: To substitute something or someone means to have them take the place of another.
Example: When I ran out of juice, I had to substitute water to drink in the morning.
Cambridge Examples:
• You can substitute oil for butter (= use oil instead of butter) in this recipe.
• You can substitute the wheat flour with almond flour (= use almond flour instead of wheat flour).
• He made his film debut when he was substituted for the actor who was originally cast.
• I took out the words "he" and "his" and substituted them with "they" and "their".

Definition: therapy is treatment for a particular physical or mental illness or condition.
Example: After she broke her legs, she used physical therapy to learn how to walk again.
Cambridge Examples:
• occupational therapy
• speech therapy
• group therapy
• Joining a club can be a therapy for loneliness.

Definition: To transfer something means to move it from one place to another.
Example: The family transferred the groceries from the shopping cart to the car.
Cambridge Examples:
• He has been transferred to a psychiatric hospital.
• She transferred her gun from its shoulder holster to her handbag.
• We were transferred from one bus into another.
• Police are investigating how £20 million was illegally transferred from/out of the trust's bank account.
• The aim is to transfer power/control/responsibility to self-governing regional councils.

Definition: When children are naughty, they behave badly or do not do what they are told.
Example: The boy had to go to his room because he was being naughty.
Cambridge Examples:
• Now that's naughty - don't throw food on the floor!
• Our boss treats us all like naughty children.

Definition: When something is ultimate, it is the final result or aim of a long series of events.
Example: By trying hard in school, I will reach my ultimate goal of becoming a doctor.
Cambridge Examples:
• Of course the ultimate responsibility for the present conflict without doubt lies with the aggressor.
• My manager will make the ultimate decision about who to employ.
• Infidelity is the ultimate betrayal.
• the ultimate luxury cruiser
Morphology: mid 17th century: from late Latin ultimatus, past participle of ultimare ‘come to an end’.

Definition: If something is antique, it is very old and rare, and therefore valuable.
Example: My grandmother’s antique rocking chair is worth a lot of money.
Cambridge Examples: • antique silver/jewellery/lace/furniture

Definition: A diplomat is a representative of a country who works with another country.
Example: The Spanish diplomat discussed trade issues with officials in Peru.
Cambridge Examples: • a Spanish/British diplomat

Definition: A refund is money given back to a person when an item is returned to a store.
Example: I asked for a refund because the shoes I bought were too tight.
Cambridge Examples: • I took the radio back to the shop and asked for/demanded/got/was given a refund.

Definition: To compromise is to agree to something that is not exactly what you want.
Example: We both compromised about the game we decided to play.
Cambridge Examples:
• Party unity is threatened when members will not compromise.
• Well, you want $400 and I say $300, so let's compromise at/on $350.

Definition: currency is the form of money used in a certain place.
Example: Elizabeth had to exchange her dollars for foreign currency.
Cambridge Examples:
• foreign currency
• Take some foreign currency to cover incidentals like the taxi fare to your hotel.
• Five people were indicted for making and selling counterfeit currency.
• The Central Bank intervened in the currency markets today to try to stabilize the exchange rate.
• The currency has lost so much of its value that barter has become the preferred way of doing business.
• In 1971, Britain switched over to a decimal currency.

Definition: A shiver is a shaking movement the body makes when someone is cold or scared.
Example: I got shivers on my way home because it was so cold.
Cambridge Examples:
• The poor dog - it's shivering!
• He shivered with cold in his thin cotton shirt.

Definition: When someone is sociable, they are friendly.
Example: Many of my good friends are sociable, but I am shy.
Cambridge Examples:
• Rob's very sociable - he likes parties.
• I had a headache and I wasn't feeling very sociable.

Definition: To disrupt something or someone is to prevent them from working.
Example: The loud crash disrupted the class lecture.
Cambridge Examples:
• Heavy snow disrupted travel into the city this morning.
• The meeting was disrupted by a group of protesters who shouted and threw fruit at the speaker.

Definition: If something or someone is absurd, they are ridiculous.
Example: That group of people making animal noises sounds completely absurd.
Cambridge Examples:
• What an absurd thing to say!
• Don't be so absurd! Of course I want you to come.
• It's an absurd situation - neither of them will talk to the other.
• Do I look absurd in this hat?

Definition: An attic is a room just below a house’s roof.
Example: There were two windows in their attic.
Cambridge Examples:
• I've got boxes of old clothes in the attic.
• an attic bedroom at the top of the house

Definition: To dissatisfy someone means to fail to please them.
Example: He was dissatisfied with his meal.
Cambridge Examples: • If you're dissatisfied with the service, why don't you complain to the hotel manager?

Definition: If something is particular, then it is a single, important part of a group of things.
Example: The dress shop didn’t have the particular dress she was looking for.
Cambridge Examples:
• She wanted a particular type of cactus.
• He wouldn't take just any book - he had to have this particular one!
• "Why did you ask?" "Oh, no particular reason, just making conversation."

Definition: To snore means to make a loud noise each time a sleeping person breathes.
Example: It was impossible to get to sleep because my husband snored.
Cambridge Examples:
• Sometimes my husband snores so loudly, it keeps me awake at night.
• Do you know any cures for snoring?

Definition: If something is exclusive, it is expensive and only for rich people.
Example: The golf course was so exclusive that most people hadn’t even heard of it.
Cambridge Examples:
• an exclusive private club
• an exclusive part of town

Definition: To socialize is to have a good time with people.
Example: I like to socialize with my classmates after school.
Cambridge Examples:
• I tend not to socialize with my colleagues.
• I hope Adam's actually doing some work at college - he seems to spend all his time socializing!

Definition: To sob is to cry loudly.
Example: I sobbed when my youngest daughter got married.
Cambridge Examples:
• I found her sobbing in the bedroom because she'd broken her favourite doll.
• You're not going to help matters by lying there sobbing!

Definition: An upbringing is the way that someone is taught to behave by their parents.
Example: He had a strict upbringing and was never allowed to watch television.
Cambridge Examples: • Is it right to say all the crimes he committed were simply the result of his upbringing?

Definition: A faucet is a device that controls the flow of a liquid or gas.
Example: Turn off the faucet when you are done brushing your teeth.
Cambridge Examples:
• the hot/cold faucet
• Turn the faucet on/off.

Definition: A stool is a seat with legs but no support for a person’s arms and back.
Example: I don’t find stools very comfortable to sit on.
Cambridge Examples:
• a bar/kitchen/piano stool
• a three-legged stool

Definition: To prohibit something means to not allow it.
Example: She prohibited the students from speaking until their work was done.
Cambridge Examples:
• Motor vehicles are prohibited from driving in the town centre.
• The government introduced a law prohibiting tobacco advertisements on TV.
• Parking is strictly prohibited between these gates.

Definition: A paw is an animal’s foot that has claws or soft bottoms.
Example: The kitten cleaned its paws with its tongue.
Cambridge Examples: • I found paw prints in the kitchen.

Definition: If something is substantial, then it is of great importance, size, or value.
Example: The bank said that he owed it a substantial amount of money.
Cambridge Examples:
• The findings show a substantial difference between the opinions of men and women.
• She inherited a substantial fortune from her grandmother.
• The first draft of his novel needed a substantial amount of rewriting.

Definition: To upgrade something means to improve it or make it more efficient.
Example: He upgraded to a real fancy car.
Cambridge Examples:
• It's very simple to upgrade the indexing software.
• Consider upgrading your buildings insurance policy every five to 10 years.
• They have not yet upgraded to fully digitial technology.

Definition: If someone is clumsy, then they are awkward in handling things.
Example: The businessman was clumsy and dropped his work files.
Cambridge Examples: • That's the third glass you've smashed this week - you're so clumsy!

Definition: To stimulate something means to cause or to increase activity in it.
Example: Doctors sometimes use electric shock to stimulate a patient’s heartbeat.
Cambridge Examples: • The government plans to cut taxes in order to stimulate the economy.

Definition: A nursery is a room where babies and children sleep, play, or are cared for.
Example: The children kissed their parents goodnight and went upstairs to the nursery.
Cambridge Examples: • Does Jake go to a nursery or a childminder?

Definition: A parcel is a package of things to be carried or mailed somewhere.
Example: The parcel looked like it had been stepped on by someone.
Cambridge Examples:
• a food parcel
• The parcel was wrapped in plain brown paper.

Definition: If something is winding, then it follows a twisting course.
Example: The winding river turned and looped around the bases of the hills.
Cambridge Examples:
• There's a very long, winding path leading up to the house.
• They struggled up the narrow winding stairs.

Definition: If something is intermediate, then it is in the middle of two levels, places, or times.
Example: He selected the intermediate ski hill to begin his afternoon of skiing.
Cambridge Examples:
• There are three levels of difficulty in this game: low, intermediate, and high.
• This novel is too difficult for intermediate students of English.

Definition: To regain something means to get it back.
Example: The battery regained its power after being recharged.
Cambridge Examples:
• The government has regained control of the capital from rebel forces.
• She made an effort to regain her self-control.

Definition: To abolish something means to put an end to it, such as a system or law.
Example: President Lincoln abolished slavery in the US.
Cambridge Examples:
• I think bullfighting should be abolished.
• National Service was abolished in the UK in 1962.

Definition: To tackle something means to deal with it in a determined and efficient way.
Example: Such social problems need to be tackled right away.
Cambridge Examples:
• There are many ways of tackling this problem.
• I tackled him about his careless work.

Definition: A coward is a person who lacks courage to do risky or dangerous things.
Example: A firefighter cannot be a coward. They have to be able to act quickly.
Cambridge Examples: • They branded her a coward for informing on her colleagues during the interrogation.

Definition: To delete something means to remove or erase written material.
Example: Several lines had been deleted from her speech.
Cambridge Examples:
• They insisted that all expletives be deleted from the article.
• Here is a list of possible answers. Please delete (= draw a line through them) as appropriate.

Definition: If someone is fluent in a language, then they are able to speak it very well.
Example: She was so fluent in German that you’d have thought she was from Germany.
Cambridge Examples:
• She's fluent in French.
• He's a fluent Russian speaker.

Definition: If something is racial, then it is related to a race or races.
Example: The differences between racial groups are physical characteristics and culture.
Cambridge Examples:
• racial discrimination/prejudice
• The law has done little to prevent racial inequality.
• She accused another contestant of using a racial slur against her.

Definition: courtesy is the excellence of manners or social conduct.
Example: Jenna always behaves with great courtesy when people visit her home.
Cambridge Examples:
• You might get along better with your parents if you showed them some courtesy.
• [ + to infinitive ] He could at least have had the courtesy to say sorry.
• The president welcomed her visitors with the usual courtesies.

Definition: To generate something means to cause it to develop or begin.
Example: The mayor promised to generate new jobs and programs to help the poor.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her latest film has generated a lot of interest/excitement.
• The new development will generate 1,500 new jobs.
• Selling food will increase the club's ability to generate revenue/income.

Definition: To export products means to sell them to other countries.
Example: The United States exports many cereals and grains.
Cambridge Examples:
• French cheeses are exported to many different countries.
• Our clothes sell so well in this country that we have no need to export.

Definition: To justify something means to show or prove that it is necessary.
Example: The government tried to justify its decision to bring the country into a war.
Cambridge Examples:
• [ + -ing verb ] I can't really justify taking another day off work.
• Are you sure that these measures are justified?

Definition: To yawn means to open one’s mouth wide and breathe in air.
Example: The child yawned and stretched her arms before bed for the night.
Cambridge Examples: • I can't stop yawning - I must be tired.

Definition: vinegar is a strong liquid made from sour wine that is used in cooking.
Example: Be careful because too much vinegar will ruin the recipe.
Cambridge Examples:
• wine vinegar
• Would you like oil and vinegar on your salad?

Definition: To revise something means to change or update it to make it better.
Example: When the editor discovered certain facts were wrong, he revised the book.
Cambridge Examples:
• His helpfulness today has made me revise my original opinion/impression of him.
• His publishers made him revise his manuscript three times.

Definition: A terrace is an open area that is connected to a house or an apartment.
Example: In the afternoons, she liked to sit on the terrace and check her email.
Cambridge Examples:
• That keeps us from working the land enough and building enough terraces.
• The building type that gradually evolved was neither a terrace house nor a block of flats.

Definition: A thermometer is a device that measures temperature.
Example: The thermometer outside the window indicated that it was a hot day today.
Cambridge Examples: • The ambient temperature was recorded using a dry bulb thermometer.

Definition: To haunt is to cause problems or negative thoughts over a long period of time.
Example: His thoughts about his scary dream haunted him for weeks.
Cambridge Examples:
• Fighting in Vietnam was an experience that would haunt him for the rest of his life.
• 30 years after the fire he is still haunted by images of death and destruction.

Definition: To assist someone is to help them.
Example: Andrew assisted me with my homework.
Cambridge Examples:
• The army arrived to assist in the search.
• You will be expected to assist the editor with the selection of illustrations for the book.

Definition: A breeze is a soft and pleasant wind.
Example: The breeze caused the leaves to fall off the tree.
Cambridge Examples:
• a warm/cool breeze
• She let the gentle breeze cool her face.

Definition: To display something is to show it, especially by putting it in a certain place.
Example: The museum displayed many wonderful paintings.
Cambridge Examples: • Family photographs were displayed on the wall.

Definition: If something or someone is efficient, they do not waste energy.
Example: My car is very efficient. I rarely have to buy gas.
Cambridge Examples:
• The city's transport system is one of the most efficient in Europe.
• We need someone really efficient who can organize the office and make it run smoothly.

Definition: To forgive someone is to stop being angry with them.
Example: Sandra forgave Peter after he said he was sorry.
Cambridge Examples:
• I don't think she's ever quite forgiven me for getting her name wrong that time.
