• I'd never forgive myself if anything happened to the kids.

Definition: If someone is lively, they have a lot of energy.
Example: Jennifer is very lively: she’s always running and playing.
Cambridge Examples:
• It's hard work teaching a class of lively children.
• a lively city
• They take a lively interest in their grandchildren.
• There was some lively discussion at the meeting.

Definition: If someone is pessimistic, they believe that the worst will happen.
Example: John is pessimistic. He always thinks something bad will happen.
Cambridge Examples:
• The tone of the meeting was very pessimistic.
• The doctors are pessimistic (= not hopeful) about his chances of recovery.

Definition: A rumor is something people talk about even though it may not be true.
Example: Kevin was spreading rumors about Marcia to everyone.
Cambridge Examples:
• Rumors are going around (the school) about Mr. Mason and his assistant.
• [ + that ] She's circulating/spreading rumors that the manager is going to resign.
• I heard a rumor that she'd been seeing Luke Harrison.
• I heard a rumor that she's leaving, but apparently there's nothing in it.
• A rumor has surfaced that the company is about to go out of business.
• The president has consistently denied the rumors.
• He denied all responsibility for the rumors that have been circulating.
• The company moved quickly to quash rumors that it is losing money.

Definition: To slap someone means to hit them with the palm of the hand.
Example: Out of anger, Helen slapped Eunice on the face.
Cambridge Examples:
• She slapped his face.
• She slapped him across the face.
• His friends slapped him on the back when he said he was getting married (= hit him lightly on the back in a friendly way to express pleasure at what he had done).
• When her ideas were rejected, she slapped her report (down) on the table and stormed out of the meeting.

Definition: To smash something is to break it into many small pieces.
Example: Jacob smashed the window with a rock.
Cambridge Examples:
• Rioters ran through the city, smashing windows and looting shops.
• She dropped her cup and watched it smash to pieces/to smithereens on the stone floor.

Definition: A subject is the topic that is being discussed or taught.
Example: The subject of Marco’s speech was the economy.
Cambridge Examples:
• Our subject for discussion is homelessness.
• She has made a series of documentaries on the subject of family relationships.
• The guest lecturer took as her subject (= decided to speak about) "punishment and imprisonment in modern society".
• The number of planes flying over the town has been the subject of (= has caused) concern since last summer.

Definition: A wage is the money that a person gets for doing a job.
Example: The wages I receive from my job are really great!
Cambridge Examples:
• a very low/high wage
• an hourly/daily/weekly/annual wage
• He gets/earns/is paid a good wage, because he works for a fair employer.
• The job pays very low wages.

Definition: You use whereas to show how two things are different.
Example: My sister loves horror movies, whereas I prefer comedies.
Cambridge Examples:
• He must be about 60, whereas his wife looks about 30.
• You eat a huge plate of food for lunch, whereas I have just a sandwich.

Definition: A concept is an idea about something.
Example: I learned some concepts of molecules before working in the science lab.
Cambridge Examples:
• The concept of free speech is unknown to them.
• It is very difficult to define the concept of beauty.
• I failed to grasp the film's central concept.
• Kleenbrite is a whole new concept in toothpaste!

Definition: To construct something means to make or build it.
Example: The men used wood and metal to construct a house.
Cambridge Examples:
• to construct a new bridge/building
• The walls are constructed of concrete.
• to construct a story/sentence/argument

Definition: A decade is a period of ten years.
Example: She celebrated her three decades of work with the company.
Cambridge Examples:
• Air traffic has increased 30% in the last decade.
• They predict that a large earthquake will strike the east coast before the end of the decade.
• Environmental awareness has increased dramatically over the past decade.
• Her acting career spanned almost six decades.
• India attained independence in 1947, after decades of struggle.

Definition: A diagram is a simple drawing that explains what something is or how it works.
Example: By following the diagram, I was able to put the desk together.
Cambridge Examples: • The teacher drew a diagram showing how the blood flows through the heart.

Definition: A ferry is a boat that carries passengers over short distances.
Example: The ferry took the people across the lake.
Cambridge Examples:
• a car ferry
• We're going to the Channel Islands by/on the ferry.
• We took the ferry to Calais.

Definition: If someone is sophisticated, they know many things about the world.
Example: Jake is one of the most sophisticated persons I’ve ever met.
Cambridge Examples:
• She was slim, svelte, and sophisticated.
• I don't think I have any books that would suit your sophisticated tastes.
• He was older than me and from London and I thought him very sophisticated.

Definition: If something is upright, it is standing up straight.
Example: Meerkats can’t walk like humans, but they can stand upright.
Cambridge Examples: • Please return your seat to an upright position and fasten your belt.

Definition: If something is worthwhile, it is important or useful.
Example: On his visit to Canada, he realized studying English was worthwhile.
Cambridge Examples:
• She considers teaching a worthwhile career.
• The time and expense involved in keeping up to date with all the changes has been worthwhile.
• If you need him on this project, you've got to make it financially worthwhile for him (= you will have to pay him a suitable amount of money for the amount of work involved).

Definition: If you are armed, you are carrying a weapon.
Example: The robber was armed with a gun.
Cambridge Examples:
• armed conflict
• These men are armed and dangerous, and should not be approached.

Definition: A ceremony is an event that happens on special occasions.
Example: Tom and Amy’s marriage ceremony is in June.
Cambridge Examples:
• a wedding/graduation ceremony
• We weren't married in church, but we had a civil ceremony in a registry office.
• The Olympics climaxed in a spectacular closing ceremony.
• The glittering ceremony conjured up images of Russia's imperial past.
• Several foreign dignitaries attended the ceremony.
• The queen, in full ceremonial dress, presided over the ceremony.

Definition: culture is the music, art, and writings of a certain place or group of people.
Example: Ancient Mexican culture is renowned for its architecture.
Cambridge Examples:
• You won't find much culture in this sleepy little town, I'm afraid!
• popular culture (= the books, music, etc. liked by most people)

Definition: A detail is a small piece of information.
Example: Jane told Ben all the details of her trip to China.
Cambridge Examples:
• She insisted on telling me every single detail of what they did to her in hospital.
• We don't know the full/precise details of the story yet.
• She refused to disclose/divulge any details about/of the plan.

Definition: When a group of things is diverse, it is made up of a wide variety of things.
Example: Big cities have diverse populations with people of different races and ages.
Cambridge Examples:
• Students from countries as diverse as Colombia and Lithuania use Cambridge textbooks.
• New York is a very culturally/ethnically diverse city.

Definition: To equip someone is to give them the things needed to do something.
Example: Steve was equipped with the tools needed to do the job.
Cambridge Examples:
• It's going to cost $4 million to equip the hospital.
• All the police officers were equipped with shields to defend themselves against the rioters.

Definition: An exception is someone or something not conforming to a rule.
Example: Most students thought the test was hard, but Tim was the exception.
Cambridge Examples:
• Men are usually quite good at map-reading but Tim is the exception.
• There are exceptions to every rule.
• I like all kinds of movies with the exception of (= but not) horror movies.
• Her books are always entertaining and this one is no exception.
• You must report here every Tuesday without exception.

Definition: An impact is the effect someone or something has on another.A strong influence.
Example: My grandmother had a great impact on my life.
Cambridge Examples:
• The anti-smoking campaign had had/made quite an impact on young people.
• The new proposals were intended to soften the impact of the reformed tax system.

Definition: shelter is (a building designed to give) protection from bad weather, danger, or attack.
Example: The frog took shelter from the storm in a nearby cave.
Cambridge Examples:
• an air-raid shelter
• They opened a shelter to provide temporary housing for the city's homeless.
• The trees gave/provided some shelter from the rain.
• There was no shelter from the merciless heat. The bomb shelter has concrete walls that are three metres thick.
• Spare a thought for all those without shelter on a cold night like this.
• An upturned boat on the beach provided shelter.
• When the air raid siren went off people ran to their shelters.

Definition: To sort means to put things in a particular order or arrange them in groups according to size, type etc
Example: The eggs are sorted according to size.
Cambridge Examples:
• Paper, plastic, and cans are sorted for recycling.
• I'm going to sort these old books into those to be kept and those to be thrown away.
• You can use the computer to sort the newspaper articles alphabetically, by date, or by subject.
• She found the ring while sorting (through) some clothes.

Definition: To supply something means to give people what they need or want, often in large quantities and over a long period of time
Example: The water heater supplied the house with warm water.
Cambridge Examples:
• Electrical power is supplied by underground cables.
• Three people have been arrested for supplying arms to the terrorists.
• The company has supplied the royal family (= provided them with something they need) for years.
• At the beginning of termthe semester, students are supplied with a list of books that they are expected to read.

Definition: An alternative is something that you can choose instead of your first choice.
Example: Her first plan to make extra money seemed weak, so she chose an alternative.
Cambridge Examples:
• The opposition parties have so far failed to set out an alternative strategy.
• An alternative venue for the concert is being sought.

Definition: To blow means to move air or move something through the air, as in the wind.
Example: The wind is blowing very hard today. We should stay inside.
Cambridge Examples:
• The wind was blowing harder every minute.
• The letter blew away and I had to run after it.
• A gale-force wind had blown the fence down.
• I blew the dust off the books.
• I wish you wouldn't blow smoke in my face.

Definition: A conflict is a fight between different people or groups.
Example: The two nations had a conflict over which one could use the water in the river.
Cambridge Examples: • We wish to avoid conflict between our countries if at all possible.

Definition: A continent is one of the seven large areas of land on the Earth.
Example: Asia is the largest continent.
Cambridge Examples:
• the North American continent
• the continents of Asia and Africa

Definition: enthusiasm is a feeling of energetic interest in a particular subject or activity and an eagerness to be involved in it.
Example: The crowd showed their enthusiasm for the soccer team by cheering loudly.
Cambridge Examples:
• One of the good things about teaching young children is their enthusiasm.
• After the accident he lost his enthusiasm for the sport.
• I just can't work up (= start to feel) any enthusiasm for the whole project.

Definition: To lean is to bend the body in a particular direction.
Example: The woman leaned against the counter because she was tired.
Cambridge Examples:
• She leaned forward and whispered something in my ear.
• I sat down next to Bernard, who leaned over to me and said "You're late."
• Lean your head back a little.
• That fence is leaning to the right.

Definition: The meantime is the time between two events.
Example: Ted began setting the table. In the meantime, I began preparing the food.
Cambridge Examples: • Your computer won't arrive till Thursday. In the meantime, you can use Jude's.

Definition: muscle is a mass of tissue attached to bone that helps you move.
Example: She went to the gym in order to make her muscles stronger.
Cambridge Examples:
• neck/back/leg/stomach muscles
• facial muscles
• bulging/rippling (= large and clear to see) muscles
• He flexed his muscles (= tightened them to make them look large and strong) so that everyone could admire them.
• These exercises build muscle and increase stamina.
• a muscle spasm (= a sudden uncontrollable tightening movement)

Definition: To rescue someone means to remove them from danger.
Example: The firefighter rescued the man from the burning building.
Cambridge Examples:
• The lifeboat rescued the sailors from the sinking boat.
• The government has refused to rescue the company from bankruptcy.

Definition: violence is an action or a word that is intended to hurt people.
Example: The boy hit his brother in an act of violence.
Cambridge Examples:
• It seems that the attack was a gratuitous/random/mindless act of violence.
• The recent outbreak/eruption of racial violence in the area is very troubling.
• The report documents the staggering amount of domestic violence against women.

Definition: to influence someone or something, or cause them to change
Example: The student’s poor attitude affected the other students in the class.
Cambridge Examples:
• Both buildings were badly affected by the fire.
• The divorce affected every aspect of her life.
• It's a disease that affects mainly older people.
• I was deeply affected by the film (= it caused strong feelings in me).

Definition: A horn is a device that makes a loud noise.
Example: The boy honked his horn while he rode his bicycle past the house.
Cambridge Examples: • The driver blew/sounded (informal honked) her horn.

Definition: A nightmare is a bad or scary dream.
Example: The girl was scared to go back to sleep because she had a nightmare.
Cambridge Examples:
• a terrifying nightmare
• I shouldn't have watched that movie - it'll give me nightmares.

Definition: A signature is your name that you have written in your own way.
Example: I put my signature at the end of the letter.
Cambridge Examples:
• I need your signature on this release document
• He accused her of forging his signature.
• collect/gather signatures We are collecting signatures for a petition.
• I mistook your signature and thought the letter was from someone else.
• Please print your name clearly below your signature.
• On display were boxing gloves which bore Rocky Marciano's signature.
• I'm not going to forge his signature for you! What do you take me for?
• His signature was an illegible squiggle at the bottom of the page.

Definition: stuff is a word used to refer to things without mentioning the things by name.
Example: We gave a lot of stuff to the charity.
Cambridge Examples:
• There's sticky stuff all over the chair.
• What's this black stuff?
• He drinks gallons of tea - he loves the stuff.

Definition: A van is a vehicle that is used for carrying things but is smaller than a truck.
Example: The delivery company uses large vans to deliver packages.
Cambridge Examples:
• a delivery van
• a Transit van
• a van driver

Definition: To warn someone is to make them know of possible danger in the future.
Example: The lifeguard warned people to stay away from the rough ocean.
Cambridge Examples:
• [ + obj + to infinitive ] We were warned not to eat the fish which might upset our stomachs.
• [ + obj + (that) ] Have you warned them (that) there will be an extra person for dinner?
• I was warned against/off going to the east coast because it was so full of tourists.
• The boating area is marked with buoys to warn off swimmers.
• There were signs warning of fog as soon as we got onto the motorway.
• This particular curry is extremely hot - be warned!
• Put that ball down now, Laura - I'm warning you (= I will punish you if you do not)!

Definition: A workout is an exercise routine that helps improve health. A period of physical exercise.
Example: She doesn’t do her workout on the weekends.
Cambridge Examples:
• a light workout
• After my workout, I have a sauna.
• Always wear good shoes for your workout.

Definition: A brick is a block of hard clay that is used for building things, such as walls.
Example: There were several bricks scattered on the ground.
Cambridge Examples:
• The chimney was made of bricks.
• red-brick houses
• He was so embarrassed - his face went brick-red (= a dark red).

Definition: To express a feeling or idea means to show others how one thinks or feels.
Example: The nurse expressed her sympathy for the sick patient.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her eyes expressed deep sadness.
• I would like to express my thanks for your kindness.
• Words can't express how happy I am.
• These figures are expressed as a percentage of the total.

Definition: To injure someone means to damage a part of their body.
Example: The car crash injured two people.
Cambridge Examples:
• A bomb exploded at the embassy, injuring several people.
• She fell and injured her shoulder.
• He was badly injured in the crash.
• He claimed that working too hard was injuring his health.

Definition: A mixture is something that is made by mixing other things together.
Example: The walls were built using a mixture of water, rock, and dirt.
Cambridge Examples:
• The mixture of flour, water, and yeast is then left in a warm place for four hours.
• Their latest CD is a mixture of new and old songs.

Definition: To ruin something means to harm or damage it greatly.
Example: Our walk in the park was ruined by the sudden rain.
Cambridge Examples:
• Huge modern hotels have ruined this once unspoilt coastline.
• Her injury ruined her chances of winning the race.

Definition: If something is slight, then it is small or minor.
Example: There was only a slight change in the little boy’s height.
Cambridge Examples:
• a slight improvement
• a slight incline
• She had a slight headache.
• I don't have the slightest idea what he's talking about.

Definition: You use although to say that one thing is contrasted by another.
Example: although she was late, her friends gave her a warm welcome.
Cambridge Examples:
• She walked home by herself, although she knew that it was dangerous.
• He decided to go, although I begged him not to.

Definition: To bury someone or something means to put them into a hole in the ground and cover them.
Example: They buried their grandfather under his favorite tree after he died.
Cambridge Examples:
• The dog trotted off to bury its bone.
• buried treasure

Definition: A climate is the usual weather in a place.
Example: The climate in the desert is very hot.
Cambridge Examples:
• a hot/dry/harsh climate
• The Mediterranean climate is good for growing citrus fruits and grapes.
• When we retire, we're going to move to a warmer climate.

Definition: When you complain, you say that you are unhappy about something.
Example: The workers complained that they were being treated unfairly.
Cambridge Examples:
• Lots of people have complained about the noise.
• You're always complaining!
• [ + that ] He complained that his boss was useless and he had too much work.

Definition: To confuse someone means to make them feel like they are unsure.
Example: The sign confused the traveler because it pointed in two directions.
Cambridge Examples:
• You're confusing him! Tell him slowly and one thing at a time.
• Stop confusing the issue (= making the problem unnecessarily difficult)!

Definition: When something is due, it is expected to happen or be done at that time.
Example: The papers were due on the 19th.
Cambridge Examples:
• What time is the next bus due?
• The next meeting is due to be held in three months' time.
• Their first baby is due in January.

Definition: When you talk about an entire thing, you are talking about the whole thing.
Example: He was so hungry that he ate the entire pizza by himself.
Cambridge Examples:
• Between them they ate an entire cake.
• He'd spent the entire journey asleep.
• They got an entire set of silver cutlery as a wedding present.

Definition: To establish something means to create it.
Example: He wanted to establish a club for people to help the Earth.
Cambridge Examples:
• The brewery was established in 1822.
• These methods of working were established in the last century.

Definition: To measure something means to find out the size or amount (B2), or quality, value, or effect of it. (C2)
Example: The scientists carefully measured the amount of chemicals in the tubes.
Cambridge Examples:
• There is no way of measuring the damage done to morale.
• "Will the table fit in here?" "I don't know - let's measure it."
• This machine measures your heart rate.
• He measured the flour into the bowl.
• The main bedroom measures 24 ft by 18 ft (24' x 18').
• Engine speed can be measured in revolutions per minute (rpm).
• The metre is the standard unit for measuring length in the SI system.
• Measure all the dry ingredients into a large mixing bowl.
• This stick is used for measuring the amount of oil in the engine - do you see the marks on it?

Definition: misery is extreme suffering.
Example: There was a lot of misery after Sam lost his dog.
Cambridge Examples:
• We have witnessed the most appalling scenes of human misery.
• Ten years of marriage to him have made her life a misery.

Definition: research is close and careful study to discover new things.
Example: Scientists did a lot of research on the subject of blood type.
Cambridge Examples:
• scientific/medical research
• a research student/assistant/laboratory
• They are carrying out/conducting/doing some fascinating research into/on the language of dolphins.
• UK His researches in the field of disease prevention produced unexpected results.

Definition: If something happens altogether, it happens completely.
Example: The company stopped using sugar altogether in its food.
Cambridge Examples:
• The government ought to abolish the tax altogether.
• She wrote less and less often, and eventually she stopped altogether.
• It's all right working with him, but living with him would be a different matter altogether.
• I'm not altogether sure I want that (= I have doubts about it).
• I think Graham will agree, but convincing Mary will be altogether more (= much more) difficult.

Definition: A bruise is a dark mark caused by being hit by something.
Example: She got a bruise on her knee from falling down.
Cambridge Examples:
• His arms and back were covered in bruises.
• She had a few cuts and bruises but nothing serious.
• One or two of the peaches had bruises on them.

Definition: A custom is a way of doing things that has been the same for a long time.
Example: It is a custom that the bride and groom have the first dance.
Cambridge Examples:
• a local/ancient custom
• [ + to infinitive ] In my country, it's the custom (for women) to get married in white.
• It's a custom which is beginning to die out.
• She covered her head out of deference to Muslim custom.
• The women gathered around the coffin and began to wail, as was the custom in the region.
• The song was a custom handed down through the generations.
Morphology: Middle English: from Old French coustume, based on Latin consuetudo, from consuetus, past participle of consuescere ‘accustom’, from con- (expressing intensive force) + suescere ‘become accustomed’.

Definition: When something is negative, it is unpleasant or sad.
Example: She doesn’t like to say negative things about her friends.
Cambridge Examples:
• The warm winter has had a very negative effect/impact on the ski industry.
• a negative attitude
• You're so negative about everything!

Definition: To rip something means to pull it apart.
Example: She ripped the paper in half by accident.
Cambridge Examples:
• His new trousers ripped when he bent down.
• I ripped my shirt on a nail.
• [ + obj + adj ] She excitedly ripped the package open.
• The wind ripped the flag to/into shreds (= into little pieces).

Definition: A source of something is the place that it comes from.
Example: The river was the source of drinking water for the village.
Cambridge Examples:
• a source of heat/energy/light
• a heat/energy/light source
• Oranges are a good source of vitamin C.
• Experts are trying to track down the source of the contamination in the water supply.
• We walked up the river to its source in the hills.
• Money is often a source of tension and disagreements in young married couples.

Definition: A civilization is an organized group of humans that have culture and government.
Example: Most early civilizations in Central America didn’t use metal weapons.
Cambridge Examples:
• Some people think that nuclear war would mean the end of civilization.
• Cuzco was the centre of one of the world's most famous civilizations, that of the Incas.

Definition: When something is convenient, it is easy to do and does not take a lot of work.
Example: The bus is a convenient way to get to school.
Cambridge Examples:
• Our local shop has very convenient opening hours.
• A bike's a very convenient way of getting around.
• [ + that ] It's very convenient that you live near the office.
• [ + to infinitive ] I find it convenient to be able to do my banking online.
• What time would it be convenient for me to come over?

Definition: To fold is to bend something like paper or cloth so that it takes up less space.
Example: I folded the paper and put it in my pocket.
Cambridge Examples:
• I folded the letter (in half) and put it in an envelope.
• He had a neatly folded handkerchief in his jacket pocket.
• Will you help me to fold (up) the sheets?
• The table folds up when not in use.

Definition: A lid is a top for a box or container that can be removed.
Example: He lifted the lid of the box and revealed her present.
Cambridge Examples:
• Can you get the lid off this jar?
• Put a lid on the saucepan.

Definition: poison is a dangerous substance that causes illness or death.
Example: They used poison to get rid of the rats in their home.
Cambridge Examples:
• The pest control officer put bowls of rat poison in the attic.
• Her drink had been laced with a deadly poison.

Definition: stormy describes something affected or characterized by storms.
Example: The golfers decided to go home because of the stormy weather.
Cambridge Examples:
• stormy weather
• The sky was dark and stormy.

Definition: When something is urban, it is related to the city.
Example: Subways are an important form of urban transportation.
Cambridge Examples:
• urban development
• urban decay

Definition: An accent is a certain way of speaking that shows where a person is from.
Example: The new teacher’s accent was clearly a German one.
Cambridge Examples:
• He's got a strong southern/Boston accent.
• She's French but she speaks with an impeccable English accent.
• He speaks with a broad/heavy/strong/thick Yorkshire accent.
• I thought I could detect a slight Canadian accent.

Definition: A barber is a person whose job is to cut hair.
Example: My hair is getting much too long. I’d better go to the barber’s shop.
Cambridge Examples: • He used to work as a barber.

Definition: A basement of a house or building is a room that is built underground.
Example: They turned their basement into a game room.
Cambridge Examples:
• Our kitchenware department is in the basement.
• a basement flat

Definition: When something is blank, it does not have anything on it.
Example: She got a blank paper to draw on.
Cambridge Examples:
• a blank sheet of paper
• a blank computer screen
• Sign your name in the blank space at the bottom of the form.

Definition: To blink means to shut the eyes and quickly open them again.
Example: I blinked many times so that my eyes could adjust to the bright light.
Cambridge Examples: • You've got something in your eye - try blinking a few times.

Definition: A choir is a group of people who sing together.
Example: He had choir practice every day after school.
Cambridge Examples:
• He sings in the church choir.
• choir practice

Definition: When something is comic, it is funny.
Example: The comic actor was famous for his jokes.
Cambridge Examples: • a comic actor/performance

Definition: To decline an offer or invitation means to say no to it.
Example: She declined his offer to pay for her dinner.
Cambridge Examples:
• I invited him to the meeting but he declined.
• He declined my offer.
• [ + to infinitive ] They declined to tell me how they had obtained my address.

Definition: To reserve something means to keep it for a certain person or time.
Example: He reserved a table at the busy restaurant.
Cambridge Examples:
• I reserve Mondays for tidying my desk and answering letters.
• These seats are reserved for the elderly and women with babies.
• I reserve judgment on this issue (= I won't give an opinion on it now) until we have more information.

Definition: A script is the words of a film or play.
Example: He read the script of the play three times.
Cambridge Examples: • Bruce Robinson wrote the script for "The Killing Fields".

Definition: To search for something or someone means to look for them carefully.
Example: I searched the newspaper for a new job.
Cambridge Examples:
• The police searched the woods for the missing boy.
• She searched his face for some sign of forgiveness, but it remained expressionless.
• He searched (in/through) his pockets for some change.
• I've searched high and low (= everywhere), but I can't find my birth certificate.
• The detectives searched the house from top to bottom (= all over it), but they found no sign of the stolen goods.
• figurative She searched her mind/memory for the man's name, but she couldn't remember it.
• figurative People who are searching after inner peace sometimes turn to religion.

Definition: To slam is to close something hard; to (cause to) move against a hard surface with force and usually a loud noise.
Example: She slammed the book shut after she finished reading it.
Cambridge Examples:
• The wind made the door/window slam (shut).
• Close the door carefully, don't slam it.
• He slammed the brakes on (= used them quickly and with force) when a child ran in front of his car.
• I had to stop suddenly, and the car behind me slammed into the back of me.

Definition: The atmosphere is the air around the Earth where weather conditions form.
Example: Scientists worry that harmful substances are hurting the atmosphere.
Cambridge Examples: • These factories are releasing toxic gases into the atmosphere.

Definition: An author is a person who wrote a certain piece of writing.
Example: The author was hard at work on his next novel.
Cambridge Examples: • He is the author of two books on French history.

Definition: A breakdown is a failure to work correctly.
Example: Her car had a breakdown, and she wasn’t sure how to fix it.
Cambridge Examples:
• I had a breakdown (= my car stopped working) in the middle of the road.
• Both sides blamed each other for the breakdown of talks.

Definition: A chapter is a part of a book that usually has a number or a title.
Example: The first chapter of a book usually introduces the main character of a story.
Cambridge Examples: • Read Chapter 10 before class tomorrow.

Definition: To connect two things means to join them together.
Example: I connected the mouse to my laptop computer.
Cambridge Examples:
• Can I connect my printer to your computer?
• Where does the stove connect (up) to the electricity?
• Has the phone/electricity/gas/internet been connected (= switched on or joined to the main supply) in your new place yet?

Definition: peas are a vegetable that is small, round and green.
Example: His favorite food was peas.
Cambridge Examples:
• frozen/dried peas
• pea soup

Definition: To state something means to say it in a definite way.
Example: The president stated his opinion about the world’s health concerns.
Cambridge Examples:
• Our warranty clearly states the limits of our liability.
• [ + (that) ] Union members stated (that) they were unhappy with the proposal.
• [ + question word ] Please state why you wish to apply for this grant.
• Children in the stated (= named) areas were at risk from a lack of food, the report said.

Definition: A tray is a flat plate used to hold food.
Example: The waiter brought our food on a tray.
Cambridge Examples: • She was carrying a tray of drinks.

Definition: If something is unfortunate, it is bad or unlucky.
Example: It was unfortunate that Dave’s team lost, but he still had fun.
Cambridge Examples:
• She has inherited her father's large nose, which is very unfortunate.
• [ + (that) ] It was unfortunate (that) he called at the exact moment when our guests were arriving.

Definition: When something is vivid, it is bright and colorful.
Example: The figures in the painting were vivid.
Cambridge Examples:
• He gave a very vivid and often shocking account/description of his time in prison.
• He's one of those people with a very vivid imagination - every time he hears a noise he's convinced it's someone breaking in.

Definition: To betray someone means to treat them in a dishonest way.
Example: The man betrayed his country when he gave away national secrets.
Cambridge Examples:
• He was accused of betraying his country during the war.
• She felt betrayed by her mother's lack of support.
• For years they betrayed the UK's secrets to Russia.
• formal He promised never to betray his wife (= never to leave her for another person).

Definition: To cease means to stop.
Example: After about an hour, the rain ceased, and a rainbow appeared.
Cambridge Examples:
• Whether the protests will cease remains to be seen.
• The company has decided to cease all UK operations after this year.
• [ + to infinitive ] Workplace nurseries will cease to be liable for tax.

Definition: To comment means to say something that shows your personal opinion.
Example: Tom commented on the poor quality of the food.
Cambridge Examples:
• My mum always comments on what I'm wearing.
• [ + that ] He commented that the two essays were rather similar.
• The official refused to/declined to comment on the matter.

Definition: A mass is a large number of things of one type.
Example: We received a mass of letters this morning.
Cambridge Examples:
• The explosion reduced the church to a mass of rubble.
• The forest is a mass of colour in autumn.

Definition: If you sweep the floor, you clean it with a tool like a broom or a brush.
Example: There is a lot of dirt on the floor. Can you sweep it please?
Cambridge Examples:
• sweep the floor
• She swept the ashes from the fireplace.
• When I arrived he was sweeping the leaves from the driveway.

Definition: A background is a person’s education, family, and experience.
Example: The new teacher had a background in science and math.
Cambridge Examples:
• The school has students from many different ethnic/cultural/religious backgrounds.
• They come from a privileged/wealthy background.
• a background in publishing

Definition: copper is a red-brown metal often used in electric wire and pipes.
Example: Ancient hunters melted copper to make knives and spears.
Cambridge Examples:
• They mine a lot of copper around these parts.
• One of the properties of copper is that it conducts heat and electricity very well.

Definition: A disease is an illness that causes specific problems.
Example: He had a disease that caused him to lose his hearing.
Cambridge Examples:
• a contagious/infectious disease
• a common/rare/incurable/fatal disease
• They reported a sudden outbreak of the disease in the south of the country.
• The first symptom of the disease is a very high temperature.
• She has caught/contracted (= begun to have) a lung disease/disease of the lungs.
• Starvation and disease have killed thousands of refugees.

Definition: to itch is to have or cause an uncomfortable feeling on the skin that makes you want to rub it with your nails.
Example: The rough fabric in his shirt made the back of his neck itch.
Cambridge Examples: • I can't wear wool - it makes me itch.

Definition: literature is books, plays, and poetry.
Example: Early American literature covers the poetry and stories from 1500 to 1800.
Cambridge Examples:
• classical/modern literature
• "Wuthering Heights" is a classic of English literature.

Definition: A myth is a traditional story that explains a culture’s history and beliefs.
Example: In Greece, there was a myth about a woman who had snakes for hair.
Cambridge Examples:
• ancient myths
• The children enjoyed the stories about the gods and goddesses of Greek and Roman myth.
• Most societies have their own creation myths.

Definition: To promote someone means to raise them to a higher position or rank.
Example: After two years in the company, she was promoted to a manager.
Cambridge Examples:
• If I'm not promoted within the next two years, I'm going to change jobs.
• She's just been promoted to senior sales rep.

Definition: A religion is a belief in a god or gods.
Example: Their religion taught that people should forgive their enemies.
Cambridge Examples: • the Christian religion

Definition: A sum is a specific amount of money.
Example: He calculated the numbers to see what the sum of his bills would be.
Cambridge Examples:
• Huge sums of money are spent on national defence.
• He sold the house for a tidy (= large) sum.
• humorous I worked for three whole weeks for which I received the princely (= very low) sum of $100.

Definition: To update something means to make it more modern.
Example: We need to update the programs on our computers.
Cambridge Examples: • an updated version of the software

Definition: charity is an act of giving help, usually money, to those who need it.
Example: Thanks to his friends’ charity, he had enough money to pay the rent.
Cambridge Examples:
• She does a lot of work for charity.
• People tend to give to (= give money to) charity at Christmas time.
• They did a charity performance on the first night, to raise money for AIDS research.

Definition: commerce is the activity of buying and selling things.
Example: The new shopping mall increased the commerce in that section of town.
Cambridge Examples: • the world of commerce and industry

Definition: If something is cozy, then it is comfortable, warm, and relaxing.
Example: The thick blanket made the bed very cozy.
Cambridge Examples:
• This room is nice and cozy in the winter.
• He showed me into a cozy little room.
• It's much better to have a small cozy room than a big cold one.
• The room looked cozy and inviting.

Definition: An economy is the money and businesses of a country or region.
Example: The factory was good for the economy because it brought jobs to the area.
Cambridge Examples:
• the global economy
• the German/US economy
• the state of the economy
• a weak/strong economy
• Tourism contributes millions of pounds to the local economy.

Definition: To hitchhike means to travel by asking for rides from passing vehicles.
Example: She didn’t have a car, so she hitchhiked several miles to her brother’s home.
Cambridge Examples:
• I would never hitchhike on my own.
• They hitchhiked to Paris.

Definition: pity is the feeling of sadness and kindness for those who are suffering.
Example: Because she had pity for the lost boy, she helped him find his parents.
Cambridge Examples:
• The girl stood gazing in/with pity at the old lion in the cage.
• She agreed to go out with him more out of pity than anything.
• These people don't want pity, they want practical help.

Definition: To reduce something means to make it less in size or number.
Example: When the store reduced its prices, people wanted to shop there.
Cambridge Examples:
• Do nuclear weapons really reduce the risk of war?
• The plane reduced speed as it approached the airport.
• My weight reduces when I stop eating sugar.
• We bought a TV that was reduced from £500 to £350 in the sales.
• I reduced the problem to a few simple questions.

Definition: A temper is someone’s mood or a chance that they might get angry.
Example: She has a temper. Even the slightest mistakes make her angry.
Cambridge Examples:
• She has a real temper.
• He's got a really bad temper.

Definition: If something is accurate, it is completely correct.
Example: The story in the newspaper wasn’t very accurate.
Cambridge Examples:
• an accurate machine
• an accurate description
• The figures they have used are just not accurate.
• Her novel is an accurate reflection of life in Spain.
• We hope to become more accurate in predicting earthquakes.

Definition: To analyze something is to study it, especially by separating it into its parts, in order to discover what it is or contains.
Example: The scientist will analyze the blood sample.
Cambridge Examples:
• Water samples taken from streams were analyzed for contamination by chemicals.
• The powder was sent to the lab to be analyzed.

Definition: A factor is something that has an effect on the way another thing happens.
Example: Smoking is the main factor that causes lung cancer.
Cambridge Examples:
• People's voting habits are influenced by political, social and economic factors.
• Heavy snow was a contributing factor in the accident.
• Price will be a major/crucial factor in the success of this new product.
• The economy is regarded as the decisive/key factor in the outcome of the election.
• informal The movie's success is largely due to its feel-good factor (= its ability to make people feel happy).

Definition: To be identical is to be the same as someone or something else.
Example: James and John are identical twins.
Cambridge Examples:
• I've got three identical blue suits.
• The two rooms were virtually identical.
• The interests of both parties may not be identical, but they do overlap considerably.
• The tests are identical to those carried out last year.

Definition: A majority of something is most of the people or things in a group
Example: A majority of the people voted for Tom Smith in the election.
Cambridge Examples:
• The majority of the employees have university degrees.
• A large majority of people approve of the death sentence.
• In Britain women are in the/a majority.

Definition: If something is vast, it is very large.
Example: The wealthy man bought a vast amount of land in the countryside.
Cambridge Examples:
• A vast audience watched the broadcast.
• The amount of detail the book contains is vast.
• The people who have taken our advice have saved themselves vast amounts/sums of money.
• The vast majority of children attend state schools.

Definition: A vegetarian is someone who does not eat any meat products.
Example: I became a vegetarian because I don’t like the taste of meat.
Cambridge Examples:
• Of the four million people who have become vegetarians in this country, nearly two thirds are women.
• Everyone I know likes the smell of bacon - even Mike does and he's a vegetarian.
• You're a vegetarian and you eat fish?
• I've been feeling much healthier since I became a vegetarian.
• She's been a vegetarian for ten years now.
• Don't tell him you're a vegetarian - it's like a red rag to a bull.

Definition: If someone is dizzy, then they feel off balance as if they will fall down.
Example: The pregnant woman was dizzy after standing up too quickly.
Cambridge Examples:
• Going without sleep for a long time makes me feel dizzy and light-headed.
• I felt dizzy with excitement as I went up to collect the award.

Definition: A saucer is a small round dish that you set a cup on.
Example: He placed the spoon on the saucer.
Cambridge Examples:
• a cup and saucer
• She gave the cat a saucer of milk (= a small amount of milk on a saucer).

Definition: If someone is tense, they are worried something bad might happen.
Example: After the phone call, Monica was very tense.
Cambridge Examples: • She was very tense as she waited for the interview.

Definition: An aircraft is a vehicle that flies in the sky, such as an airplane or helicopter.
Example: At the museum in the airport, you can see a lot of old aircraft.
Cambridge Examples: • military aircraft

Definition: A celebrity is someone who is famous, esp. in the entertainment business, or the state of being such person.
Example: It was the highlight of the evening when the celebrities arrived.
Cambridge Examples:
• Being recognized in the street is part and parcel of being a celebrity.
• The success of her book has given her unexpected celebrity status.
• The celebrity guests turned up dressed in sumptuous evening gowns.
• She loves to read about the lives of celebrities.

Definition: concrete is a substance made from stones.
Example: The man covered the ground with concrete.
Cambridge Examples:
• reinforced concrete
• a concrete floor/path
• a grey concrete building

Definition: If someone is decisive, they make decisions quickly.
Example: Our boss is very decisive, so it did not take long to organize the project.
Cambridge Examples:
• You need to be more decisive.
• a decisive reply

Definition: An institute is an organization that is interested in research or teaching.
Example: I am going to a lecture about ancient Rome at the Historical institute.
Cambridge Examples:
• the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
• The institute derives all its money from foreign investments.
• The institute will invest 5 million in the project.
• The state of Michigan has endowed three institutes to do research for industry.
• The research institute is based in Cambridge.
• The institute awards three research fellowships each year.

Definition: If a place is rural, it is in the countryside instead of the city.
Example: I want to live in a small house in a rural area.
Cambridge Examples: • The area is still very rural and undeveloped.

Definition: A species is a type of plant or animal.
Example: There are 21 different species of butterfly in this forest.
Cambridge Examples:
• Mountain gorillas are an endangered species.
• Over a hundred species of insect are found in this area.

Definition: A crisis is a situation that is extremely stressful or dangerous.
Example: The airport workers’ strike led to a crisis at the airport.
Cambridge Examples:
• crisis talks
• A mediator has been called in to resolve the crisis.
• It may yet be possible to find a peaceful solution to the crisis.
• The country is in the midst of an economic crisis.
• Talks were held in Madrid about the fuel crisis.
• Falling house prices are illustrative of the crisis facing the construction industry.
• The two groups will meet next week to try to defuse the crisis.
• The media never tire of telling us that Europe is somehow "in crisis".
• Plastic surgery is fine for people with a strong self-image but bad for people "in crisis" - getting divorced, coping with a death, or who've just lost a job, for example.

Definition: To cure means to cause an illness or injury to end or disappear.
Example: My dentist cured me of my toothache.
Cambridge Examples: • At one time doctors couldn't cure TB/cure people of TB.

Definition: An embassy is where government officials work in a foreign country.
Example: If you lose your passport, you should contact the embassy.
Cambridge Examples: • The Ambassador held a reception at the embassy.

Definition: If something happens promptly, it happens quickly or on time.
Example: Arrive promptly, or we won’t have time to discuss everything.
Cambridge Examples:
• We'll have to leave fairly promptly (= on time) if we want to catch that train.
• We try to answer readers' letters as promptly (= quickly) as we can.
• She promised she'd keep it secret and promptly (= immediately after) went and told Dad!

Definition: If something is beneficial, it is good for you.
Example: Drinking milk everyday is beneficial to your bones.
Cambridge Examples:
• The improvement in sales figures had a beneficial effect/influence on the company as a whole.
• A stay in the country will be beneficial to his health.

Definition: The capacity of something is the amount of things that can be put in it.
Example: The parking lot has reached its full capacity.
Cambridge Examples:
• The stadium has a seating capacity of 50,000.
• The game was watched by a capacity crowd/audience of 50,000 (= the place was completely full).
• The generators each have a capacity of (= can produce) 1,000 kilowatts.
• The larger cars have bigger capacity engines (= the engines are bigger and more powerful).
• All our factories are working at (full) capacity (= are producing goods as fast as possible).
• We are running below capacity (= not producing as many goods as we are able to) because of cancelled orders.

Definition: If something is crucial, it is extremely important to another thing.
Example: Clean air is crucial to the survival of humans, plants, and animals.
Cambridge Examples:
• a crucial decision/question
• Her work has been crucial to the project's success.
• [ + that ] It is crucial that the problem is tackled immediately.

Definition: To distribute something is to give it to a number of people.
Example: The teacher distributed crayons and markers to his students.
Cambridge Examples:
• The books will be distributed free to local schools.
• Several people were arrested for distributing racist leaflets/pamphlets (to the spectators).
• The company aims eventually to distribute (= supply for sale) its products throughout China.

Definition: exotic describes something unusual because it is from far away.
Example: Rebecca tried many exotic foods on her trip to Africa.
Cambridge Examples: • exotic flowers/food/designs

Definition: An objective is a goal or plan that someone has.
Example: My objective this week is to finish my homework by 7:30 every night.
Cambridge Examples:
• Her main/prime objective now is simply to stay in power.
• Can the sales team achieve/meet its financial objectives?

Definition: oxygen is a gas that all living things need to breathe.
Example: My aunt believes that the oxygen in the country is cleaner than in the city.
Cambridge Examples:
• Air is composed mainly of nitrogen and oxygen.
• Deep-sea divers carry cylinders of oxygen on their backs.
• Mountain climbers use oxygen when they reach higher altitudes.
• Plants are the main source of atmospheric oxygen.
• The symbol for oxygen is O2.

Definition: A rainforest is a forest that is in a place where it rains very often.
Example: The rainforest is home to many animals.
Cambridge Examples: • a tropical rainforest

Definition: A strategy is a plan for how to do something.
Example: The team came up with a strategy to win the game.
Cambridge Examples:
• The president held an emergency meeting to discuss military strategy with the Pentagon yesterday.
• Their marketing strategy for the product involves obtaining as much free publicity as possible.
• [ + to infinitive ] We're working on new strategies to improve our share of the market.

Definition: To expand is to become bigger in size.
Example: A balloon will expand as you blow air into it.
Cambridge Examples:
• The air in the balloon expands when heated.
• They expanded their retail operations during the 1980s.

Definition: To define means to clearly state, show, or explain what something is.
Example: People define success in many different ways.
Cambridge Examples:
• Your rights and responsibilities are defined in the citizens' charter.
• Your role in the project will be strictly defined (= limited to particular areas).
• I'd hate to feel that I was defined by (= that my life got its meaning and importance only from) my job.

Definition: A candidate is a person who is competing to win something such as a job.
Example: Alice is the best candidate for the job.
Cambridge Examples: • There are three candidates standing in the election.

Definition: An era is a period of time that has something special about it.
Example: During the medieval era, knights wore protective armor.
Cambridge Examples:
• the Jefferson era
• a bygone (= past) era
• the post-war era
• They had worked for peace during the long era of conflict.
• The fall of the Berlin wall marked the end of an era.

Definition: To interact is to talk to or do something with another person.
Example: The kids began to interact when the adults left the room.
Cambridge Examples:
• Dominique's teacher says that she interacts well with the other children.
• It's interesting at parties to see how people interact socially.
• We are studying how these two chemicals interact.

Definition: To pollute means to make air, water, or land dirty, unclean, or foul.
Example: The careless factory polluted the river with chemicals.
Cambridge Examples:
• The pesticides used on many farms are polluting the water supply.
• We won't invest in any company that pollutes the environment.
• figurative Many complain that broadcasters pollute the airwaves with sensationalism and sleaze.

Definition: If something is solar, it is related to the sun.
Example: Using solar energy is good for the environment.
Cambridge Examples:
• solar radiation
• solar flares
• a solar cell/panel
• solar heating

Definition: A territory is a piece of land that belongs to a country but isn’t a state.
Example: Gibraltar is a territory of Great Britain.
Cambridge Examples:
• He was shot down in enemy territory.
• The UN is sending aid to the occupied territories.

Definition: A tournament is a competition, usually with many people participating.
Example: My dad is playing in a golf tournament tomorrow.
Cambridge Examples:
• a tennis/chess/golf tournament
• They were defeated in the first round of the tournament.

Definition: transportation is any type of vehicle that can carry people or things.
Example: I don’t have a car, so my normal transportation is the train.
Cambridge Examples: • Bicycles are a cheap and efficient form/means of transportation.

Definition: chaos is a situation that is confusing and not ordered.
Example: His presentation was in chaos. I couldn’t understand what he meant.
Cambridge Examples:
• Snow and ice have caused chaos on the roads.
• Ever since our secretary walked out, the office has been in a state of total/utter chaos.
• We muddled up the name labels and chaos ensued (= resulted).

Definition: If food is organic, it is grown without adding chemicals to it.
Example: The organic carrots are more expensive, but they’re better for you.
Cambridge Examples: • organic food/fruit/farms/farmers

Definition: A tornado is a tube-shaped formation of air that spins very quickly.
Example: During a tornado, the safest place to be is underground.
Cambridge Examples:
• A tornado is not a danger in itself, it is only dangerous if it comes in contact with something else.
• We can do nothing about natural forces—cyclones, hurricanes, tornadoes, drought and so on.
• We must not assume that tornadoes will not hit this country.

Definition: A nuisance is a person or thing that is annoying or causes a lot of problems.
Example: The teenager considered her noisy little brothers to be quite a nuisance.
Cambridge Examples:
• I've forgotten my umbrella - what a nuisance!
• [ + -ing verb ] It's such a nuisance having to rewrite those letters.
• I hate to be a nuisance, but could you help me?
• Local residents claimed that the noise was causing a public nuisance.

Definition: To be content is to be happy and not want more.
Example: The baby looked very content sitting on the floor.
Cambridge Examples:
• He seems fairly content with (his) life.
• [ + to infinitive ] They're content to socialize with a very small circle of people.

Definition: To found means to bring something into existence.
Example: The pastor founded his church in the countryside.
Cambridge Examples:
• Boston was founded in 1630 by Puritan colonists from England.
• She left a large sum of money in her will to found a wildlife sanctuary.
• We are planning a dinner to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the founding of the company.

Definition: When something happens frequently, it happens often.
Example: We meet frequently, either at the beginning or ending of the week.
Cambridge Examples:
• frequently asked questions
• I see him frequently.
• The buses run less frequently on Sundays.
